question: Question 1 A controller [latex]D(s)[/latex] of the form [latex]\left(1+K_{D} s\right)[/latex] is to be designed for the plant [latex]G(s)=\frac{1000 \sqrt{2}}{s(s+10)^{2}}[/latex] as shown in the figure. The value of [latex]\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{D}}[/latex] that yields a phase margin of [latex]45^{\circ}[/latex] at the gain cross-over frequency of [latex]10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec}[/latex] is ___________ (round off to one decimal place).
solution:
Given phase margin [P.M] [latex]=45^{\circ}[/latex] at gain cross over frequency [latex]\left[\omega_{\mathrm{gc}}\right]=10[/latex] O.L.T.F with controller [latex]=\mathrm{G}_{\mathrm{c}}(\mathrm{s})=\mathrm{D}(\mathrm{s}) . \mathrm{G}(\mathrm{s})[/latex] [latex]
\begin{gathered}
\mathrm{G}_{\mathrm{c}}(\mathrm{~s})=\frac{\left[1+\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{D}} \mathrm{~S}\right] \times 1000 \sqrt{2}}{\mathrm{~s}[\mathrm{~s}+10]^{2}} \\
\text { P.M }=180^{\circ}+\left.\angle \mathrm{G}_{\mathrm{c}}(\mathrm{~s})\right|_{\omega=\omega_{\mathrm{gc}}} \\
\text { Given P.M }=45^{\circ} \text { at } \omega_{\mathrm{gc}}=10 \\
45^{\circ}=180^{\circ}+\angle \frac{1000 \sqrt{2}\left[1+\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{D}} \mathrm{~s}\right.}{} \mathrm{s}[\mathrm{~s}+10]^{2} \\
45^{\circ}=\left[180^{\circ}-90^{\circ}+\tan ^{-1}\left[\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{gc}} \mathrm{~K}_{\mathrm{D}}}{1}\right]-2 \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{gc}}=10}{10}\right)\right]_{\mathrm{\omega gc}}=10 \\
45^{\circ}=90^{\circ}+\tan ^{-1}\left[10 \mathrm{~K}_{\mathrm{D}}\right]-2 \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{10}{10}\right) \\
45^{\circ}=90^{\circ}+\tan ^{-1}\left[10 \mathrm{~K}_{\mathrm{D}}\right]-2 \times 45^{\circ} \\
\tan ^{-1}\left[10 \mathrm{~K}_{\mathrm{D}}\right]=45^{\circ} \\
10 \mathrm{~K}_{\mathrm{D}}={\tan 45^{\circ}=1}\\{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{D}}=\frac{1}{10}=0.1}
\end{gathered}
[/latex]

Step 1: Write the state matrix [latex] A = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \ -2 & -3 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] Step 2: Find the characteristic equation We compute the determinant of [latex] sI - A [/latex]: [latex] \det(sI - A) = \left| \begin{array}{cc} s & -1 \ 2 & s + 3 \end{array} \right| = s(s + 3) - (-2)(1) = s^2 + 3s + 2 [/latex] Step 3: Find the roots of the characteristic equation [latex] s^2 + 3s + 2 = 0 [/latex] Factorizing: [latex] (s + 1)(s + 2) = 0 \Rightarrow s = -1, -2 [/latex] Step 4: Compute the sum of the magnitudes of the poles [latex] |{-1}| + |{-2}| = 1 + 2 = 3 [/latex]

question: Question 3 Let [latex]\mathrm{G}(\mathrm{s})=\frac{1}{(\mathrm{s}+1)(\mathrm{s}+2)}[/latex]. Then the closed-loop system shown in the figure below, is
solution: Step 1: Open-loop transfer function: [latex] G(s) = \frac{1}{(s+1)(s+2)} [/latex], So the forward path becomes: [latex] K(s-1)G(s) = \frac{K(s-1)}{(s+1)(s+2)} [/latex] Step 2: Closed-loop transfer function (unity feedback): [latex] T(s) = \frac{K(s-1)G(s)}{1 + K(s-1)G(s)} = \frac{K(s-1)}{(s+1)(s+2) + K(s-1)} [/latex] Step 3: Characteristic equation: [latex] (s+1)(s+2) + K(s-1) = 0 [/latex] Compute: [latex] s^2 + 3s + 2 + K(s - 1) = 0 [/latex] [latex] s^2 + 3s + 2 + Ks - K = 0 [/latex] [latex] s^2 + (3 + K)s + (2 - K) = 0 [/latex] Step 4: Apply Routh-Hurwitz criterion: For a second-order system [latex] s^2 + a_1 s + a_0 [/latex] to be stable, both coefficients must be positive: [latex] a_1 = 3 + K > 0 \Rightarrow \text{always true for } K > -3 [/latex] [latex] a_0 = 2 - K > 0 \Rightarrow K < 2 [/latex] So the system is stable for [latex] K < 2 [/latex], and unstable for [latex] K \geq 2 [/latex]. Final Answer: (B) unstable for all [latex] K \geq 2 [/latex]

question: Question 5 The Nyquist plot of a strictly stable [latex]G(s)[/latex] having the numerator polynomial as [latex](s-3)[/latex] encircles the critical point [latex]-1[/latex] once in the anti-clockwise direction. Which one of the following statements on the closed-loop system shown in figure, is correct?
solution: Given: The Nyquist plot of a strictly stable transfer function [latex]G(s)[/latex] has the numerator polynomial [latex](s - 3)[/latex], and it encircles the critical point [latex]-1[/latex] once in the anti-clockwise direction. Step 1: Understand the Nyquist criterion The Nyquist criterion provides a relationship between the open-loop transfer functionâ€™s Nyquist plot and the stability of the closed-loop system. According to the Nyquist criterion, the number of encirclements of the critical point [latex]-1[/latex] determines the stability of the closed-loop system. Step 2: Analyze the information given The Nyquist plot encircles the critical point [latex]-1[/latex] once in the anti-clockwise direction. The open-loop transfer function is strictly stable, implying that all poles are in the left half of the complex plane. The system's Nyquist plot encircles the critical point [latex]-1[/latex] once in the anti-clockwise direction. According to the Nyquist criterion, this indicates that the number of right-half-plane poles of the open-loop transfer function is 1. Step 3: Apply the Nyquist criterion for stability The Nyquist criterion states that for the closed-loop system to be stable, the number of encirclements of the point [latex]-1[/latex] must be equal to the number of right-half-plane poles of the open-loop transfer function. Since the Nyquist plot encircles [latex]-1[/latex] once in the anti-clockwise direction, the number of right-half-plane poles is 1. This suggests that the closed-loop system is unstable because the number of encirclements of [latex]-1[/latex] is non-zero, and the system has a pole in the right half of the complex plane. Final Answer: The system is unstable.

Question 6 Selected data points of the step response of a stable first-order linear time-invariant (LTI) system are given below. The closest value of the time-constant, in sec, of the system is [latex]\begin{array}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline
Time(sec) & 0.6 & 1.6 & 2.6 & 10 & \infty \\
\hline
Output & 0.78 & 1.65 & 2.18 & 2.98 & 3 \\
\hline
\end{array}
[/latex]
solution: Step 1: Analyze the step response of a first-order LTI system For a first-order LTI system, the step response is given by: [latex]y(t) = K \left(1 - e^{-t/\tau}\right)[/latex] Where [latex]K[/latex] is the steady-state value (final output), and [latex]\tau[/latex] is the time constant. Step 2: Use the steady-state value The output approaches the steady-state value as [latex]t \to \infty[/latex]. At [latex]t = \infty[/latex], the output is 3, which is the steady-state value (K). Thus, [latex]K = 3[/latex]. Step 3: Relating time and output For a first-order system, the time at which the output reaches [latex]63%[/latex] of the final value is equal to the time constant [latex]\tau[/latex]. So, [latex]y(\tau) = K \left(1 - e^{-1}\right) = 3 \times (1 - e^{-1}) \approx 3 \times 0.632 = 1.896[/latex]. Step 4: Find the closest data point to 1.896 Looking at the given data points, at [latex]t = 1.6 \text{ sec}, y(t) = 1.65[/latex], which is the closest to 1.896. Thus, the time constant [latex]\tau \approx 2 \text{ sec}[/latex]. Final Answer: The closest value of the time constant is [latex]2 \text{ sec}[/latex].

Question 16 A continuous-time system that is initially at rest is described by [latex]
\frac{d y(t)}{d t}+3 y(t)=2 x(t)
[/latex] where [latex]x(t)[/latex] is the input voltage and [latex]y(t)[/latex] is the output voltage. The impulse response of the system is

solution:
Given plant: So, [latex]\quad[/latex] OLTF [latex]=\frac{(3 s+1)}{s(s-1)}[/latex] Closed loop transfer function, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\frac{Y(s)}{R(s)} & =\frac{3 s+1}{s^{2}+2 s+1} \\
Y(s) & =\frac{3 s+1}{s\left(s^{2}+2 s+1\right)} \quad\left[\because R(s)=\frac{1}{s}\right]
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Final value of plant, [latex]
Y(\infty)=\operatorname{Lims}_{s \rightarrow 0} Y(s)=1
[/latex] From plant, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
X(\mathrm{~s}) & =\left[\mathrm{R}(\mathrm{s})-\frac{\mathrm{X}(\mathrm{s})}{\mathrm{s}-1}\right]\left(3+\frac{1}{\mathrm{~s}}\right) \\
X(\mathrm{~s})\left[1+\frac{3 \mathrm{~s}+1}{\mathrm{~s}(\mathrm{~s}-1)}\right] & =\left(\frac{3 \mathrm{~s}+1}{\mathrm{~s}^{2}}\right)\left[\because \mathrm{R}(\mathrm{s})=\frac{1}{\mathrm{~s}}\right] \\
X(\mathrm{~s})\left[\frac{\mathrm{s}^{2}+2 s+1}{\mathrm{~s}(\mathrm{~s}-1)}\right] & =\left(\frac{3 \mathrm{~s}+1}{\mathrm{~s}^{2}}\right) \\
\Rightarrow \quad X(\mathrm{~s}) & =\frac{(3 \mathrm{~s}+1)(\mathrm{s}-1)}{\mathrm{s}\left(\mathrm{s}^{2}+2 \mathrm{~s}+1\right)}
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Final value of controller, [latex]
x(\infty)=\operatorname{LimsX}_{s \rightarrow 0} \mathrm{~s}(\mathrm{~s})=-1
[/latex]

Nyquist Contour : Given: [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{G}(\mathrm{s}) \mathrm{H}(\mathrm{s}) & =\frac{3 \mathrm{~s}+5}{\mathrm{~s}-1} \\
\text { Put } \quad \mathrm{s} & =R e^{j \theta} \\
\mathrm{G}(\mathrm{s}) \mathrm{H}(\mathrm{s}) & =\operatorname{Lim}_{R \rightarrow \infty} \frac{3 R e^{j \theta}+5}{\operatorname{Re}^{j \theta}-1} \\
\mathrm{G}(\mathrm{s}) \mathrm{H}(\mathrm{s}) & =3
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

solution: [latex]\dot{x}=-x-K x=x(-k I-I)[/latex] Characteristic equation, [latex] \begin{aligned} |S I+K I+I| &=0 \\ |(S+1+K) I| &=0 \\ \therefore \qquad\qquad S+1+K &=0 \\ S &=-1-K \\ -2 &=-1-K \\ K &=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

solution:

1+\frac{20}{s^{2}(s+1)(s+20)}&=0\\ (s^{3}+s^{2})(s+20)+20&=0\\ s^{4}+20s^{3}+s^{3}+20s^{2}+20&=0\\ s^{4}+21s^{3}+20s^{2}+20&=0 
\end{aligned}[/latex] Given system is fourth order system and unstable. stablity status: since it has one missing term
of 's' thus undoubtedly given transfer function is unstable.

question:
Question 33 Consider a negative unity feedback system with forward path transfer function
[latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{(s+a)(s-b)(s+c)}[/latex], where K, a, b, c are positive real numbers. For a Nyquist
path enclosing the entire imaginary axis and right half of the s-plane in the clockwise
direction, the Nyquist plot of [latex](1 + G(s))[/latex], encircles the origin of [latex](1 + G(s))[/latex]-plane once
in the clockwise direction and never passes through this origin for a certain value of
K. Then, the number of poles of [latex]\frac{G(s)}{1+G(s)}[/latex] lying in the open right half of the s-plane is
_________ .
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}O.L.T.F = G(s) &=\frac{K}{(s+a)(s-b)(s+c)} \\ N &= P - Z ;   \; \;P = 1 \\
-1 &= 1 - Z ; \; \;   N = -1 \\
Z &= 2\end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 35 Consider a linear time-invariant system whose input r(t) and output y(t) are related by
the following differential equation. [latex]\frac{d^2y(t)}{dt^2}+4y(t)=6r(t)[/latex] The poles of this system are at
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}\frac{d^2 y(t)}{dt^{2}}+4y(t) &=6 r(t)\\ [s^{2}+4]Y(s)&=6 R(s) \\ \frac{Y(s)}{R(s)}&=\frac{6}{s^{2}+4} \\ \text{Poles: } s^{2}+4&=0 \\ s&=\pm j2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 Consider a state-variable model of a system [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \dot{x_1}\\ \dot{x_2} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 0 &1 \\ -\alpha &-2\beta \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_1\\ x_2 \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ \alpha \end{bmatrix}r[/latex] [latex]y=[1\;\;0]\begin{bmatrix} x_1\\ x_2 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] where y is the output,  and r is  the  input.  The  damping  ratio [latex]\xi[/latex] and the undamped natural frequency [latex]\omega _n[/latex] (rad/sec) of the system are given by
solution: Characteristic equation is, [latex]|sI-A|=0 [/latex] [latex]|sI-A|=\begin{vmatrix} s &-1 \\ \alpha &s+2\beta \end{vmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=s^2+2s\beta +\alpha =0 [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; \omega _n^2=\alpha [/latex] [latex]\;\;\; \omega _n=\sqrt{\alpha } [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;2\xi \omega _n=2\beta [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;\xi =\frac{\beta }{\sqrt{\alpha }}[/latex]

question: Question 37 The transfer function of a phase lead compensator is given by [latex]D(s)=\frac{3\left ( s+\frac{1}{3T} \right )}{\left ( s+\frac{1}{T} \right )}[/latex] The frequency (in rad/sec), at which [latex]\angle D(j\omega )[/latex] is maximum, is
solution: [latex]T(s)=\frac{1+3Ts}{1+Ts}[/latex] Frequency at which  [latex]\angle T(j\omega )[/latex] is maximum, [latex](\omega _m)=\frac{1}{T\sqrt{\alpha }} [/latex] [latex]\alpha =\frac{1}{1/3}=3 [/latex] [latex]\omega _m=\frac{1}{T\sqrt{3}}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{3T^2}}[/latex]

question: Question 38 The asymptotic Bode magnitude plot of a minimum phase transfer function G(s) is shown below. Consider the following two statements. Statement I: Transfer function G(s) has three poles and one zero. Statement II: At very high frequency ([latex]\omega \rightarrow \infty[/latex]), the phase angle [latex]\angle G(j\omega)=-\frac{3\pi}{2}[/latex]. Which one of the following options is correct?
solution: [latex]G(s)=\frac{k}{s\left ( 1+\frac{s}{1} \right )\left ( 1+\frac{s}{20} \right )}[/latex] Transfer function shows 2 poles and no zeros. So statement I is false. [latex]\angle G(j\omega )=-90-tan^{-1}\omega -tan^{-1}\frac{\omega }{20} [/latex] [latex]\angle G(j\omega )|_{\omega \rightarrow \infty }=-270^{\circ}=-\frac{3\pi}{2} \;rad[/latex] So statement II is true.

options.A: Statement I is true and statement II is false.
options.B: Statement I is false and statement II is true.

question: Question 39 The characteristic equation of a linear time-invariant (LTI) system is given by [latex]\Delta (s)=s^4+3s^3+3s^2+s+k=0[/latex] The system is BIBO stable if
solution: Routh array is For BIBO stability, [latex]\frac{\left ( \frac{8}{3}-3k \right )}{\left ( \frac{8}{3} \right )} \gt 0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow k \lt \frac{8}{9} [/latex] and [latex] k \gt 0 [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; 0 \lt k \lt \frac{8}{9}[/latex]

question: Question 40 The open loop transfer function of a unity feedback system is given by [latex]G(s)=\frac{\pi e^{-0.25s}}{s}[/latex] In G(s) plane, the Nyquist plot of G(s) passes through the negative real axis at the point
solution: [latex]\angle G(j\omega )=-0.25 \times \frac{180\omega _{pc}}{\pi}-90^{\circ}=-180^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]-0.25 \times \frac{180\omega _{pc}}{\pi}=-90^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] \omega _{pc}=\frac{4\pi}{2}=2\pi [/latex] [latex]|G(j\omega )|_{\omega =\omega _{pc}}=\left | \frac{\pi e^{-0.25s}}{s} \right |_{\omega =\omega _{pc}}[/latex] [latex] =\frac{\pi}{2\pi}=0.5[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]  Point is [latex](-0.5,j0)[/latex]

question: Question 41 The unit step response y(t) of a unity feedback system with open loop transfer function [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{K}{(s+1)^{2}(s+2)}[/latex] is shown in the figure. The value of K is _______ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: Closed loop transfer function, [latex]\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{\frac{K}{(s+1)^2(s+2)}}{1+\frac{K}{(s+1)^2(s+2)}} [/latex] [latex]\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{K}{(s+1)^2(s+2)+K} [/latex] Given [latex] R(s)=\frac{1}{s} [/latex] [latex]C(s)=\frac{K}{s((s+1)^2(s+2)+K)} [/latex] [latex]\lim_{s \to 0}sC(s)=0.8 [/latex] [latex]\frac{K}{2+K}=0.8 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; K=8[/latex]

question: Question 42 The number of roots of the polynomial, [latex]s^{7}+s^{6}+7s^{5}+14s^{4}+31s^{3}+73s^{2}+25s+200[/latex], in the open left half of the complex plane is
solution: Characteristic equation, [latex]s^7+s^6+7s^5+14s^4+31s^3+73s^2+25s+200=0[/latex] Auxillary equation, [latex]A(s)=8s^4+48s^2+200 [/latex] [latex]\frac{d}{ds}A(s)=32s^3+96s[/latex] Total number of poles =7 Two sign change above auxillary equation=2 poles in RHS. Two sign changes below auxillary equation implies out of 4 symmetric roots about origin, two poles are in LHS and two poles are in RHS. Therefore 3 poles in LHS and 4 poles in RHS.

question: Question 43 C onsider a unity feedback system with forward transfer function given by [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{(s+1)(s+2)}[/latex] The steady-state error in the output of the system for a unit-step input is _________(up to 2 decimal places).
solution: Steady state error for type-0 and step input, [latex]e_{ss}=\frac{1}{1+k+p} [/latex] [latex]k_p=\lim_{s \to 0}\frac{1}{(s+1)(s+2)}=\frac{1}{2} [/latex] [latex]e_{ss}=\frac{1}{1+\frac{1}{2}}=\frac{2}{3}[/latex] [latex]\;\;=0.66[/latex] uinits

question: Question 46 Consider the system described by the following state space representation [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \dot{x_{1}(t)}\\ \dot{x_{2}(t)} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1\\ 0&-2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} {x_{1}(t)}\\ {x_{2}(t)} \end{bmatrix} +\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} u(t)[/latex] [latex]  y(t)=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} {x_{1}(t)}\\ {x_{2}(t)} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] If u(t) is a unit step input and [latex]\begin{bmatrix} {x_{1}(0)}\\ {x_{2}(0)} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}[/latex], the value of output y(t) at t = 1 sec (rounded off to three decimal places) is_________
solution: [latex]y(t)=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \end{bmatrix}x(t) [/latex] [latex]x(t)=L^{-1}[(sI-A)^{-1}]x(0)+L^{-1}[(sI-A)^{-1}]BU(s) [/latex] [latex]L^{-1}[(sI-A)^{-1}]x(0)=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]L^{-1}[(sI-A)^{-1}]BU(s)=\begin{bmatrix} -0.25+0.5t+0.25e^{-2t}\\ 0.5-0.5e^{-2t} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; x(t)=\begin{bmatrix} 0.75+0.5t+0.25e^{-2t}\\ 0.5-0.5e^{-2t} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; y(t)=0.75+0.5t+0.25e^{-2t} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;y(1)=1.284[/latex]

question: Question 47 The root locus of the feedback control system having the characteristic equation [latex]s^{2}+ 6Ks +2s +5 =0 \;  where \; K \gt 0[/latex], enters into the real axis at
solution: [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{6Ks}{s^2+2s+5}[/latex] The point at which root locus enters real axis (break away point) is given by [latex]\frac{dK}{ds}=0 [/latex] [latex]K=-\frac{(s^2+2s+5)}{6s} [/latex] [latex]\frac{dK}{ds}=0\;\Rightarrow \;s=\pm \sqrt{5} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;s=-\sqrt{5}[/latex]

question:
Question 50 When a unit ramp input is applied to the unity feedback system having closed loop transfer
function [latex]\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{Ks+b}{s^{2}+as+b}(a \gt 0,b \gt 0,K\gt 0)[/latex], the steady state error will be
solution: Closed loop transfer function [latex]=\frac{Ks+b}{s^2+as+b} [/latex] Open loop transfer function [latex]= G(s)=\frac{Ks+b}{s^2+as+b-Ks-b} [/latex] [latex]G(s)=\frac{Ks+b}{s^2+as-Ks} =\frac{Ks+b}{s(s+a-K)} [/latex] Steady state error for ramp input given to type-1 system [latex]=1/K_V[/latex] where, velocity error coefficient, [latex]K_V=\lim_{s \to 0}s\cdot \frac{Ks+b}{s(s+a-K)} =\frac{b}{a-K}[/latex] Steady state error, [latex] e_{ss}=\frac{a-K}{b}[/latex]

question: Question 51 For a system having transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{-s+1}{s+1}[/latex], a unit step input is applied at time t=0. The value of the response of the system at t=1.5 sec is __________.
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned} 
G(s)&=\frac{-s+1}{s+1} \\
&\text{System output,} \\  Y(s)&=G(s)\cdot \frac{1}{s} \\ &=\frac{-s+1}{s+1}\cdot \frac{1}{s} \\ &=\frac{1}{s}-\frac{2}{s+1} \\ y(t)&=u(t)-2e^{-t}u(t)\\ y(1.5)&=1-2e^{-1.5} \\ &=1-0.466=0.554
\end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 55 A closed loop system has the characteristic equation given by [latex]s^{3}+Ks^{2}+(K+2)s+3=0[/latex]. For this system to be stable, which one of the following conditions should be satisfied?
solution: Characteristic equation is, [latex]s^3+Ks^2+(K+2)s+3=0[/latex] For this system to be stable, using Routh's criterion, we can write, [latex]3 \lt K(K+2) [/latex] or,   [latex]K^2+2K-3 \gt 0 [/latex] or, [latex](K+3)(K-1) \gt 0[/latex] Here, the valid answer will be out of all the options given. [latex] i.e K \gt 1.[/latex]

question: Question 56 Consider the unity feedback control system shown. The value of K that results in a phase margin of the system to be [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex] is _______.
solution: Forward path transfer function,[latex]G(s)=\frac{Ke^{-s}}{s} [/latex] Given, Phase margin [latex]=30^{\circ} [/latex] Phase margin [latex]=180^{\circ}+\phi[/latex] [latex] 30^{\circ}=180^{\circ}+\phi [/latex] [latex]\phi =-150^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]\phi =\angle G(j\omega )_{\omega =\omega _{gc}} [/latex] [where [latex]\omega _{gc}[/latex] is gain crossover frequency ] [latex] \angle G(j\omega )=-90^{\circ}-57.3\omega ^{\circ}[/latex] At [latex] \omega =\omega _{gc}[/latex] [latex] |G(j\omega )|=1 [/latex] [latex]\frac{k \times 1}{\omega }=1 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \omega =\omega _{gc}=K \; rad/sec.[/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;  \angle G(j\omega )_{\omega =\omega _{gc}}=-90^{\circ}-57.3K^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]-90^{\circ}-57.3K^{\circ}=-150^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]-57.3K^{\circ}=60^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]K=\frac{60}{57.3}=1.047[/latex]

question: Question 57 The transfer function of a system is given by [latex]\frac{V_{o}(s)}{V_{i}(s)}=\frac{1-s}{1+s}[/latex] Let the output of the system be [latex]v_{o}(t)=V_{m} sin(\omega t + \varphi )[/latex] for the input [latex]v_{i}(t)=V_{m} sin(\omega t )[/latex]. Then the minimum and maximum values of [latex]\varphi[/latex] (in radians) are respectively
solution: [latex]\frac{V_o(s)}{V_i(s)}=\frac{1-s}{1+s}=H(s) [/latex] For the minimum and maximum values of [latex]'\phi '[/latex] [latex] H(j\omega )=\frac{1-j\omega }{1+j\omega }[/latex] [latex] \angle H(j\omega )=-2 tan^{-1}\omega [/latex] At [latex] \omega =0;  \;\; \; \angle H(j\omega )=0^{\circ} [/latex] At  [latex] \omega =\infty ; \;\;\; \angle H(j\omega )=-\pi[/latex]

question: Question 58 The gain at the breakaway point of the root locus of a unity feedback system with open loop transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{Ks}{(s-1)(s-4)}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]OLTS\Rightarrow G(s)=\frac{Ks}{(s-1)(s-4)}[/latex] Now, characteristic equation, [latex]1+G(s)H(s)=0[/latex] [latex] \frac{Ks}{(s-1)(s-4)}+1=0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;\; Ks+(s^2-5s+4)=0 [/latex] [latex]\;\;K=-\frac{(s^2-5s+4)}{s}=\left [ s-5+\frac{4}{s} \right ][/latex] For break away point [latex]: \frac{dK}{ds}=0[/latex] [latex] \frac{dK}{ds}=-\left [ 1-0-\frac{4}{s^2} \right ]=0 [/latex] We get, [latex]s=\pm 2[/latex] Therefore valid break away point is s=2 Now gain at s=2 is K=(Product of distances from all the poles to break away point)/(Product of distances from all the zero to break away point) Gain, [latex]K=\frac{1 \times 2}{2}=1[/latex]

question: Question 59 A second-order real system has the following properties: a) the damping ratio [latex]\xi[/latex] = 0.5 and undamped natural frequency [latex]\omega _{n}[/latex]=10 rad/s, b) the steady state value of the output, to a unit step input, is 1.02. The transfer function of the system is
solution: Damping ratio  [latex]\xi=0.5[/latex] Undamped natural frequency [latex]\omega _n=10[/latex]  rad/sec Steady state output toa unit step input [latex]C_{ss}=1.02[/latex] Hence steady state error [latex]e_{ss}=1.02-1.00=0.02[/latex] [latex] \because[/latex] Characteristic equation is, [latex]s^2+2 \xi \omega _ns+\omega _n^2=0 [/latex] [latex]s^2+2 \times 0.5\times 10 s+100=0 [/latex] [latex]s^2+10s+100=0[/latex] From options, if we take option (B) then [latex] C_{ss}=\lim_{s \to 0}s\cdot C(s) [/latex] [latex]\;\; \; \; \;=\lim_{s \to 0 }s \times \frac{1}{s} \times \frac{102}{s^2+10s+100} [/latex] [latex]C_{ss}=1.02[/latex] Hence, Option (B) is correct answer.

question: Question 60 Consider a linear time invariant system [latex]\dot{x}=Ax[/latex], with initial condition [latex]x(0)[/latex] at t=0. Suppose [latex]\alpha \; and \; \beta[/latex] are eigenvectors of (2 x 2) matrix A corresponding to distinct eigenvalues [latex]\lambda_{1} \; and \;  \lambda _{2}[/latex] respectively. Then the response [latex]x(t)[/latex] of the system due to initial condition [latex]x(0)=\alpha[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\dot{x}=Ax[/latex] Eigen values are [latex]\lambda _1[/latex] and [latex]\lambda _2[/latex] we can write, [latex]\phi (t)=\begin{bmatrix} e^{\lambda _1 t} & 0\\ 0& e^{\lambda _2 t} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] Response due to initial conditions, [latex]x(t)=\phi (t)x(0) [/latex] [latex]x(t)=\begin{bmatrix} e^{\lambda _1 t} & 0\\ 0& e^{\lambda _2 t} \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} \alpha \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex]=\alpha e^{\lambda _1 t}[/latex]

question: Question 61 The open loop transfer function of a unity feedback control system is given by [latex]G(s)=\frac{K(s+1)}{s(1+Ts)(1+2s)}, K\gt 0,T \gt 0[/latex] The closed loop system will be stable if,
solution: Open loop transfer function: [latex]G(s)=\frac{K(s+1)}{s(1+Ts)(1+2s)};[/latex]  [latex] \; K \gt 0 \; [/latex] and [latex]\; t \gt 0[/latex] For closed loop system stability, characteristic equation is, [latex]1+G(s)H(s)=0[/latex] [latex] 1+\frac{K(s+1)}{s(1+Ts)(1+2s)}\cdot 1=0[/latex] [latex] s(1+Ts)(1+2s)+K(s+1)=0 [/latex] [latex]2Ts^3+(2+T)s^2+(1+K)s+K=0 [/latex] Using Routh's criteria, For stability, [latex]K \gt 0[/latex] and  [latex] (2+T)(1+K)-2TK \gt 0 [/latex] [latex]K(2+T-2T)+(2+T) \gt 0 [/latex] or [latex] -(T-2)K+2(2+T) \gt 0 [/latex] [latex]-K \gt -\frac{(2+T)}{(T-2)}[/latex] or  [latex] K \lt \frac{T+2}{(T-2)} [/latex] Hence for stability, [latex]0 \lt K \lt \frac{T+2}{T-2}[/latex]

question: Question 62 For the network shown in the figure below, the frequency (in rad/s) at which the maximum phase lag occurs is, ___________.
Question 63 Given the following polynomial equation [latex]s^{3}+5.5s^{2}+8.5s+3=0[/latex], the number of roots of the polynomial, which have real parts strictly less than -1, is ________ .
solution: [latex]s^3+5.5s^2+8.5s+3=0 [/latex] Putting,  [latex] s=s_1-1 [/latex] [latex](s_1-1)^3+5.5(s_1-1)^2+(8.5)(s_1-1)+3=0 [/latex] [latex]s_1^3+2.5s_1^2+0.5s_1-1=1[/latex] As there is one sign change, hence, two roots of given polynomial will lie to the left of [latex]s=-1[/latex].

question: Question 64 Loop transfer function of a feedback system is [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{s+3}{s^{2}(s-3)}[/latex]. Take the Nyquist contour in the clockwise direction. Then, the Nyquist plot of G(s)H(s) encircles -1+ j0
solution: Nyquist plot of [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{s+3}{s^2(s-3)}[/latex] is as shown below From the Nyquist plot G(s)H(s) encircle -1+j0 once in clockwise direction. Alternate Solution: Characteristic equation, [latex]1+G(s)H(s)=0[/latex] [latex] s^2(s-3)+(s+3)=0 [/latex] [latex]s^3-3s^2+s+3=0 [/latex] using Routh's array [latex]\left.\begin{matrix} s^3\\ s^2\\ s^1\\ s \end{matrix}\right|\begin{matrix} 1 &1 \\ -3& 3\\ 2& 0\\ 3& \end{matrix} [/latex] There are two sign changes, hence two poles in right side of s-plane exist. [latex]Z=2, \; P=1 [/latex] [latex]N=P-Z=-1 [/latex] One encirclement in clockwise direction.

question: Question 65 Consider the following asymptotic Bode magnitude plot ([latex]\omega[/latex] is in rad/s). Which one of the following transfer functions is best represented by the above Bode magnitude plot?
solution: From the given Bode plot, it is evident that there are 3(three) poles in the transfer function, out of which there are double poles at corner frequency near but less than [latex]\omega=8[/latex] rad/sec and one pole is near but greater than [latex]\omega=0.5[/latex] rad/sec. The initial slope is +20 dB/dec. Therefore one zero exist at s=0. So from all the given options, option (A) satisfies all the conditions. Therefore Option (A) is correct.

question: Question 66 The phase cross-over frequency of the transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{100}{(s+3)^{3}}[/latex] in rad/s is
solution: [latex]G(s)=\frac{100}{(s+1)^3} [/latex] [latex]G(j\omega )=\frac{100}{(1+j\omega )^3} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{100}{1+(j\omega )^3+3(j\omega )^2+3j\omega } [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{100}{(1-3\omega^2 )+j(3\omega-\omega^3)} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{100[(1-3\omega^2 )+j\omega(3-\omega^2)^2]}{[ (1-3\omega^2 )+\omega^2(3-\omega^2)^2]} [/latex] For phase corssover frequency [latex]\omega_{ph} Img[G(j \omega )]=0;[/latex] Hence, [latex]\omega (3-\omega ^2)=0[/latex] [latex] \omega =0; \pm \sqrt{3}[/latex] Therefore, [latex]\omega _{ph}=\sqrt{3} [/latex] rad/sec

question: Question 67 For the system governed by the set of equations: [latex]dx_{1}/dt=2x_{1}+x_{2}+u [/latex] [latex]dx_{2}/dt=-2x_{1}+u [/latex] [latex] y=3x_{1}[/latex] the transfer function Y(s)/U(s) is given by
solution: [latex]\frac{dx_1}{dt}=2x_1+x_2+u\;\;\;...(i) [/latex] [latex]\frac{dx_2}{dt}=-2x_1+4\;\;\;\;...(ii)[/latex] From equation (i), [latex]sx_1=2x_1+x_2+u [/latex] [latex]sx_2=-2x_1+u [/latex] [latex]x_2=\left ( -\frac{2x_1+u}{s} \right ) [/latex] [latex]sx_1=2x_1+\left ( -\frac{2x_1+u}{s} \right )+4 [/latex] [latex]sx_1-2x_1+\frac{2x_1}{s}=\frac{4}{5}+4 [/latex] [latex]x_1\left ( s-2+\frac{2}{s} \right )=u\left (1+\frac{1}{s} \right ) [/latex] [latex]\frac{x_1}{4}=\frac{\left ( 1+\frac{1}{s} \right )}{\left ( s-2+\frac{2}{s} \right )} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\;\frac{y}{u}=\frac{3x-1}{u}=\frac{3\left ( 1+\frac{1}{s} \right )}{\left ( s-2+\frac{2}{s} \right )} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\;\frac{y}{u}=\frac{3(s+1)}{(s^2-2s+2)}[/latex]

question: Question 68 An open loop transfer function G(s) of a system is [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+1)(s+2)}[/latex] For a unity feedback system, the breakaway point of the root loci on the real axis occurs at,
solution: [latex]G_1(s)=\frac{k}{s(s+1)(s+2)} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; 1+\frac{k}{s(s+1)(s+2)}=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; s(s^2+3s+2)+k=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; s^3+3s^2+2s+k=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; k=-s^3-3s^2-2s\;\;\;...(i) [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\;\frac{dk}{ds}=0[/latex] [latex] \;\;\;\;\frac{dk}{ds}=-3s^2-6s-2=0[/latex] [latex] \;\;\;\;s=-0.422,-1.577[/latex] Only s=-0.422 lie on root locus. Therefore brakaway point is s=-0.42.

question: Question 69 The unit step response of a system with the transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{1-2s}{1+s}[/latex] is given by which one of the following waveforms?
solution: [latex]T.F.=\frac{1-2s}{1+s} [/latex] [latex]C(s)=\frac{1-2s}{1+s}\cdot \frac{1}{s} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{A}{1+s}+\frac{B}{s} [/latex] For A, [latex]A=\lim_{s \to -1}(s+1)\cdot \frac{1-2s}{s(1+s)} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{(1-2(-1))}{(-1)}=-3 [/latex] For B, [latex]B=\lim_{s \to 0}s\cdot \frac{1-2s}{s(1+s)}=1 [/latex] [latex]C(s)=\frac{1}{s}-\frac{3}{1+s} [/latex] [latex]C(t)=(1-3e^{-t})u(t)[/latex]

question: Question 70 Nyquist plots of two functions [latex]G_1(s) \;and \; G_2(s)[/latex] are shown in figure. Nyquist plot of the product of [latex]G_1(s) \;and \; G_2(s)[/latex] is
solution: [latex]G_1(s)=\frac{1}{s} [/latex] [latex]G_2(s)=s [/latex] [latex]G_1(s) \times G_2(s)=\frac{1}{s}\cdot s=1[/latex]

question: Question 71 An open loop control system results in a response of [latex]e^{-2t}(sin 5t+cos 5t)[/latex] for a unit impulse input. The DC gain of the control system is ______.

Question 72 The open loop poles of a third order unity feedback system are at 0, -1, -2. Let the frequency corresponding to the point where the root locus of the system transits to unstable region be K. Now suppose we introduce a zero in the open loop transfer function at -3, while keeping all the earlier open loop poles intact. Which one of the following is TRUE about the point where the root locus of the modified system transits to unstable region?
solution: [latex]\frac{K(s+3)}{s(s+1)(s+2)} [/latex] [latex]P=3, \; Z=1 [/latex] [latex]P-Z=3-1=2[/latex] asymptotes angle [latex]=90^{\circ}, 180^{\circ} [/latex] Centroid [latex]=\frac{(-3)-(-3)}{2}=0[/latex] as root locus never cross asymptotes so, will remain in left sideof x-axis.

options.A: It corresponds to a frequency greater than K
options.B: It corresponds to a frequency less than K
options.C: It corresponds to a frequency K
options.D: Root locus of modified system never transits to unstable region

question: Question 73 Find the transfer function [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}[/latex] of the system given below.
solution: [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}=\frac{G_1+G_2}{1-(-G_1H-G_2H)} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\frac{G_1+G_2}{1+G_1H+G_2H)}[/latex]

question: Question 74 The transfer function of a second order real system with a perfectly flat magnitude response of unity has a pole at (2-j3). List all the poles and zeroes.
solution: Response of transfer function is unit for all [latex]\omega[/latex]. [latex]M=1; P_1=2-j3[/latex] Second order system, hence number of poles =2 Therefore, second pole [latex] P_2=2+j3[/latex] Now for M=1, and due to x-axis symmetry of root locus of transfer function, position of zeroes must be [latex]Z_1=-2-j3[/latex] and [latex]Z_2=-2+j3[/latex]

options.B: Poles at ([latex]\pm[/latex]2-j3), one zero at origin.

question: Question 75 In the signal flow diagram given in the figure, [latex]u_{1} \; and \; u_{2}[/latex] are possible inputs whereas [latex]y_{1} \; and \;  y_{2}[/latex] are possible outputs. When would the SISO system derived from this diagram be controllable and observable?
solution: Equations from the flow diagram,[latex]\dot{x}_1=5x_1-2x_2+u_1 [/latex] [latex]y_1=x_1 [/latex] [latex]\dot{x}_2=5x_1+x_2+u_1+u_2 [/latex] [latex]y_2=x_1-x_2 [/latex] [latex]\dot{x}=\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2\\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}x+\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \\ 1& 1 \end{bmatrix}u [/latex] [latex]y=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ 1 & -1 \end{bmatrix}x [/latex] Considering the SISO cases:[/latex] [latex] 1. \;\;u_1(input)[/latex] and [latex] y_1(output):[/latex] [latex] A\triangleq\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2\\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]B\triangleq\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] and  [latex] C=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]O\triangleq\begin{bmatrix} C\\ CA \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ 5 & -2 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; Rank (O)=2[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;  Observable [/latex] [latex]C\triangleq\begin{bmatrix} B & AB \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &3 \\ 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \; Rank(C)\neq 2[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; non-controllable [/latex] [latex]2.\;\;u_2(input) [/latex] and  [latex] y_1(output): [/latex] [latex]A\triangleq\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2\\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]B\triangleq\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] and  [latex] C\triangleq \begin{bmatrix} 1 &-1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]O\triangleq\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ 5 & -2 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; Rank (O)=2[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; Observable [/latex] [latex]C\triangleq\begin{bmatrix} 0 &-2 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; Rank(C)=2[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; controllable [/latex] [latex]3. \;\;u_2(input) [/latex] and [latex] y_2(output) : [/latex] [latex]Rank(O)\neq 2\Rightarrow[/latex] non-observable [latex]Rank(C) =2 \Rightarrow [/latex] controllable [latex]4. \; \; u_1 (input) [/latex] and [latex] y_2(output)[/latex]: non-observale and non-controllable.

options.A: When [latex]u_{1}[/latex] is the only input and [latex]y_{1}[/latex] is the only output
options.B: When [latex]u_{2}[/latex] is the only input and [latex]y_{1}[/latex] is the only output
options.C: When [latex]u_{1}[/latex] is the only input and [latex]y_{2}[/latex] is the only output
options.D: When [latex]u_{2}[/latex] is the only input and [latex]y_{2}[/latex] is the only output

question: Question 76 For the signal-flow graph shown in the figure, which one of the following expressions is equal to the transfer function [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{X_{2}(s)}|_{X_{1}(s)=0}[/latex]?
Question 77 A Bode magnitude plot for the transfer function G(s) of a plant is shown in the figure. Which one of the following transfer functions best describes the plant?
solution: From initial line equation, [latex]20 dB=20log_{10}K[/latex] as we know, [latex]20 dB=20log_{10}K[/latex] [latex] K=10[/latex] now, from the given plot we know type of system is one. Hence, [latex]G(s)=\frac{K(1+sT_1)}{(1+sT_2)} [/latex] [latex]T_1=\frac{1}{10}; \;\;T_2=\frac{1}{1000}[/latex] [latex] G(s)=\frac{10(1+0.001s)}{(1+0.1s)} =\frac{(1000+s)}{10(s+10)}[/latex]

question: Question 78 The magnitude Bode plot of a network is shown in the figure The maximum phase angle [latex]\phi _{m}[/latex] and the corresponding gain [latex]G _{m}[/latex] respectively, are
solution: From the given Bode plot, it is clear that corner frequencies, [latex]\omega _{c1}=\frac{1}{3}[/latex] and [latex]\omega _{c2}=1[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex]  Transfer function of given system is given by [latex]T(s)=\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\left [ \frac{1+3s}{1+s} \right ]=\left [ \frac{1+Ts}{1+\alpha Ts} \right ] [/latex] Here, [latex]T=3[/latex] and  [latex]\alpha T=1,[/latex] [latex] \alpha =\frac{1}{3}[/latex] As  [latex] \alpha \lt 1[/latex], therefore the transfer function T(s) represents a lead compensator having [latex]\alpha =\frac{1}{3}[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex]   Maximum phase shift, [latex]\phi _{m}=tan^{-1}\left [ \frac{1-\alpha }{2\sqrt{\alpha }} \right ][/latex] [latex]=tan^{-1}\left [ \frac{1-\frac{1}{3}}{\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}} \right ][/latex] [latex]=tan^{-1}\left [ \frac{2}{3}\times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right ][/latex] [latex]=tan^{-1}\left [ \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \right ]=30^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; \phi _m=30^{\circ}[/latex] Also, [latex]T(j\omega )=\frac{1+j3\omega }{1+j\omega } [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;  |T(j\omega )|=\frac{\sqrt{1+9\omega ^2}}{\sqrt{1+\omega ^2}} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; Gain G_m[/latex] in dB [latex]=20log |T(j\omega )| [/latex] [latex]=20 log_{10}\left [ \frac{\sqrt{1+9\omega ^2_m}}{1+\omega ^2_m} \right ][/latex] Now, [latex] \omega _m=\frac{1}{T\sqrt{\alpha }}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; G_m=20 log_{10}\left [ \sqrt{\frac{1+9\times \left ( \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \right )^2}{1+\left ( \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \right )^2}} \right ][/latex] [latex]=20 log_{10}\left [ \sqrt{\frac{1+3}{1+\frac{1}{3}}} \right ]=20 log_{10}\sqrt{3} [/latex] [latex]G_m=4.77dB[/latex]

question: Question 79 Consider the system described by following state space equations [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \dot{x_{1}}\\ \dot{x_{2}} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1\\ -1& -1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_{1}\\ x_{2} \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}u; [/latex] [latex] y=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_{1}\\ x_{2} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] If u is unit step input, then the steady state error of the system is
solution: Given [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1\\ -1&-1 \end{bmatrix}, [/latex] [latex]B=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}, [/latex][latex]C=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] Transfer function of the given system is given by [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{U(s)}=C(sI-A)^{-1}B [/latex] Now, [latex] (sI-A)=\begin{bmatrix} s & 0\\ 0 & s \end{bmatrix}-\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1\\ -1&-1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\begin{bmatrix} s & -1\\ 1&s+1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex](sI-A)^{-1}=\frac{1}{|sI-A|}(Adj[A]) [/latex] [latex]|sI-A|=s(s+1)+1=(s^2+s+1) [/latex] and [latex] Adj[A]=\begin{bmatrix} s+1 & 1\\ -1&s \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;(sI-A)^{-1}=\frac{1}{(s^2+s+1)}\begin{bmatrix} s+1 & 1\\ -1&s \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Transfer function, [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{U(s)}=\frac{1}{(s^2+s+1)}\left \{ \begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} s+1 & 1\\ -1&s \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \right \} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{(s^2+s+1)}\left \{ \begin{bmatrix} (s+1) & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\right \}[/latex] [latex] \;\;=\frac{1}{(s^2+s+1)} \times 1 [/latex] [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{U(s)}=\frac{1}{(s^2+s+1)} [/latex] Given, input=unit step [latex] \therefore \;\;  U(s)=\frac{1}{s} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; Y(s)=\frac{1}{s}\frac{1}{(s^2+s+1)}=\frac{1}{s(s^2+s+1)} [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Final Value [latex]\lim_{s\rightarrow 0}[sY(s)][/latex] [latex]=\lim_{s\rightarrow 0}\left [ \frac{1}{(s^2+s+1)} \right ]=1 [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;[/latex] Error=Final value -Initial value [latex]e_{ss}=0[/latex]

question: Question 80 The block diagram of a system is shown in the figure If the desired transfer function of the system is [latex]\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{s}{s^{2}+s+1}[/latex] then G(s) is
solution: For all given values of G(s) in options, G(s) does not satisfy the desired condition. But option (B) is official answer given by IIT.

question:
Question 81 A single-input single output feedback system has forward transfer function G(s)
and feedback transfer function H(s). It is given that |G(s)H(s)| [latex]\lt[/latex]1. Which of
the following is true about the stability of the system ?

options.B: The system is stable if all zeros of G(s)H(s) are in left half of the s-plane
options.C: The system is stable if all poles of G(s)H(s) are in left half of the s-plane
options.D:
It is not possible to say whether or not the system is stable from the
information given

question:
Question 82 The signal flow graph of a system is shown below. U(s) is the input and C(s) is
the output Assuming [latex]h_{1}=b_{1} \; and \;  h_{0}=b_{0}-b_{1}a_{1}[/latex], the input-output transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{C(s)}{U(s)}[/latex] of the system is given by
solution: Using Mason's gain fomlula, Transfer function, [latex]G(s)=\frac{C(s)}{U(s)}=\frac{\Sigma P_k\Delta _k}{\Delta } [/latex] Forward paths are: [latex]P_1=\frac{h_0}{s^2} ,\; P_2=\frac{h_1}{s} [/latex] Individual loops are: [latex] L_1=\frac{-a_1}{s} , \; L_2=\frac{-a_0}{s^2} [/latex] Non-touching loops=zero [latex] \therefore \;\;\Delta _1=1, [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;\; \Delta _2=1-\left ( \frac{-a_1}{s} \right ) =\left ( 1+\frac{a_1}{s} \right ) =\left ( \frac{s+a_1}{s} \right ) [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;\;\Delta =1-\left ( \frac{-a_1}{s}-\frac{a_0}{s^2} \right )=\frac{s^2+a_1s+a_0}{s^2} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; G(s)=\frac{C(s)}{U(s)}=\frac{P_1\Delta _1+P_2\Delta _2}{\Delta } [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;\;=\frac{\left ( \frac{h_0}{s^2} \right )\times 1+\left ( \frac{h_1}{s} \right )\times \left ( \frac{s+a_1}{s} \right )}{\frac{s^2+a_1s+a_0}{s^2}} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\left [ \frac{h_0+h_1(s+a_1)}{s^2+a_1s+a_0} \right ] [/latex] Given:  [latex] h_1=b_1 [/latex] and [latex]h_0=b_0-b_1a_1[/latex] Thus,  [latex] G(s)=\frac{(b_0-b_1a_1)+b_1(s+a_1)}{(s^2+a_1s+a_0)} [/latex] [latex]G(s)=\left ( \frac{b_1s+b_0}{s^2+a_1s+a_0} \right )[/latex]

question: Question 83 The second order dynamic system [latex]\frac{dX}{dt}=PX+Qu  [/latex] [latex] y=RX[/latex] has the matrices P, Q and R as follows : [latex]P=\begin{bmatrix} -1 &1 \\ 0&-3 \end{bmatrix}\; Q=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \; R=\begin{bmatrix} 0 &1 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The system has the following controllability and observability properties:
solution: Given: [latex]\dot{x}(t)=Px+Qu [/latex] [latex]y=Rx [/latex] [latex]P=\begin{bmatrix} -1 &1 \\ 0& -3 \end{bmatrix} [/latex],  [latex]Q=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}[/latex],   [latex] R=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] For controllability, [latex] Q_c=\begin{bmatrix} Q &PQ \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex] [PQ]=\begin{bmatrix} -1 &1 \\ 0& -3 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -3 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; Q_c=\begin{bmatrix} 0 &1 \\ 1& -3 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;|Q_c|=-1\neq 0\Rightarrow \;\; controllable [/latex] Also, for observability, [latex] Q_0=\begin{bmatrix} R^T & P^TR^T \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\begin{bmatrix} P^T & R^T \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} -1 & 0\\ 1 & -3 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ -3 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;Q_0=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0\\ 1 & -3 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; |Q_0|=(0 \times -3 -0 \times 1)=0\Rightarrow \;\; non-observable[/latex] Since, [latex] Q_c\neq 0[/latex] and [latex]Q_0=0[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex]  System is controllable but not observable.

question: Question 84 For the transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{5(s+4)}{s(s+0.25)(s^{2}+4s+25)}[/latex] The values of the constant gain term and the highest corner frequency of the Bode plot respectively are
solution: Given, [latex]G(s)=\frac{5(s+4)}{s(s+0.25)(s^2+4s+25)} [/latex] Reducing G(s) in time constant form, we have: [latex] G(s)=\frac{5 \times 4\left ( 1+\frac{s}{4} \right )}{s\left [ 0.25\left ( 1+\frac{s}{0.25} \right ) \right ]\left [ 25\left ( 1+\frac{4}{25}s+\frac{1}{25}s^2 \right ) \right ]} [/latex] [latex]=\frac{20(1+0.25s)}{s[0.25(1+4s)][25(1+0.16s+0.04s^2)]} [/latex] [latex]G(s)=\frac{3.2(1+0.25s)}{s(1+4s)(1+0.16s+0.04s^2)} [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]  The value of constant gain term =3.2 Also,  [latex]G(j\omega )=\frac{3.2\left ( 1+\frac{j\omega }{4} \right )}{(j\omega)\left ( 1+\frac{j\omega}{0.25} \right )\left ( 1+j0.16\omega -\frac{\omega ^2}{25} \right )} [/latex] Corner frequencies are: [latex]\omega _1=4[/latex] rad/sec [latex]\omega _2=0.25[/latex] rad/sec [latex] \omega _3=5[/latex] rad/sec [latex] \therefore[/latex]  Highest corner frequency [latex]=\omega _3=5[/latex] rad/sec

question: Question 85 A system with the open loop transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+2)(s^{2}+2s+2)}[/latex] is connected in a negative feedback configuration with a feedback gain of unity. For the closed loop system to be marginally stable, the value of K is ______
solution: Given, [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+2)(s^2+2s+2)}[/latex] The characteristic equation of given unity-negative feedback control system is given by [latex]1+G(s)H(s)=0[/latex] or,  [latex] 1+\frac{K}{s(s+2)(s^3+2s+2)}=0 [/latex] or,  [latex]s(s+2)(s^3+2s+2)+K=0 [/latex] or,  [latex]s^4+4s^3+6s^2+4s+K=0 [/latex] Forming Routh' array as shown below For stability of the system, [latex]K \gt 0[/latex] and [latex]\frac{20-4K}{5} \gt 0 [/latex]or [latex]K\gt 5 [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]  For stability,  [latex]0 \lt K \lt 5[/latex] For given system to be marginally stable K=5

question: Question 86 The state transition matrix for the system [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \dot{x_{1}}\\ \dot{x_{2}} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ 1&1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_{1}\\ x_{2} \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}u[/latex] is
solution: Given: [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \dot{x}_1\\ \dot{x}_2 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ 1&1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_1\\ x_2 \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}u [/latex] or, [latex]\;\; \dot{x}(t)=Ax(t)+Bu [/latex] Here, [latex] [A]=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ 1&1 \end{bmatrix}, \;\;  B=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] State transition matric is given by, [latex]e^{At}=L^{-1}[sI-A]^{-1}[/latex] Now, [latex]  [sI-A]=\begin{bmatrix} s-1 & \\ 0 -1 & s-1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]Adj[sI-A]=\begin{bmatrix} s-1 & \\ 1 & s-1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] and [latex] |sI-A|=(s-1)^2 [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; [sI-A]^{-1}=\frac{1}{|sI-A|}Adj[sI-A] [/latex] [latex][sI-A]^{-1}=\frac{1}{(s-1)^2}\begin{bmatrix} s-1 & \\ 1 & s-1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{s-1} & \\ \frac{1}{(s-1)^2} & \frac{1}{s-1} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; L^{-1}[sI-A]^{-1}=\begin{bmatrix} e^t & 0\\ te^t& e^t \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex]  State transition matrix[latex]=\begin{bmatrix} e^t & 0\\ te^t& e^t \end{bmatrix}[/latex]

question:
Question 87 The closed-loop transfer function of a system is [latex]T(s)=\frac{4}{(s^{2}+0.4s+4)}[/latex]. The steady
state error due to unit step input is _____.
solution: Closed loop transfer function, [latex]T(s)=\frac{4}{(s^2+0.4s+4)} [/latex] or, [latex]\frac{G(s)}{1+G(s)}[/latex] [latex]=\left ( \frac{4}{s^2+0.4s+4} \right )\;\;\;\;[H(s)=1] [/latex] or,  [latex](s^2+0.4s+4)=4+4G(s) [/latex] or,   [latex]G(s)=\frac{4}{s(s+0.4)} [/latex] =Open llop transfer function ( for unity feedback system) Given, input =u(t)=r(t) [latex]\therefore \;\;\; R(s)=1/s [/latex] Steady state error [latex]e_{ss}=\lim_{s \to 0}\left [ \frac{sR(s)}{1+G(s)H(s)} \right ] [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\lim_{s \to 0}\left [ \frac{sR(s)}{1+G(s)} \right ]\;\;\; [For H(s)=1] [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\lim_{s \to 0}\left [ \frac{s \times \frac{1}{s}}{1+\frac{4}{s(s+0.4)}} \right ][/latex] [latex] \;\;=\lim_{s \to 0}\left [ \frac{s(s+0.4)}{s^2+0.4s+4} \right ]=0 [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]  Steady state error for step input, [latex]e_{ss}=0[/latex]

question: Question 88 The Bode magnitude plot of the transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{K(1+0.5s)(1+as)}{s(1+\frac{s}{8})(1+bs)(1+\frac{s}{36})}[/latex] is shown below: Note that -6 dB/octave =- 20 dB/decade. The value of [latex]\frac{a}{bK}[/latex] is _____.
solution:
Given, [latex]G(s)=\frac{K(1+0.5s)(1+as)}{s(1+\frac{s}{8})(1+bs)(1+\frac{s}{36})}[/latex] (1+as) is addition of zero to the transfer function whose contribution in slope=+20 dB/decade or -6 dB/octave. (1+bs) is addition of pole to the transfer function whose contribution in slope=-20 dB/decade or -6 dB/octave. Observing the change in the slope at different corner frequencies, we conclude that, [latex]
a=\frac{1}{4}[/latex] rad/s and [latex]b=\frac{1}{24}[/latex] rad/s From[latex] \omega =0.01[/latex] rad/s to [latex]\omega =8[/latex] rad/s, slope=-20dB/decade Let the vertical length in dB by y [latex]\therefore \;\; -20=\left ( \frac{0-y}{log8-log0.01} \right )[/latex] [latex] \;\;\;\; -20=\frac{y}{log 8+2}[/latex] [latex]
\;\;\;\; y=58 dB[/latex] Applying, [latex]y-mx+C[/latex] at [latex]\omega =0.01[/latex] rad/s, We have, [latex]58=-20log 0.01 +C[/latex] [latex]C=58-40=18[/latex] Now, [latex]C=20logK[/latex] [latex]
LogK=\frac{18}{20}=0.9[/latex] [latex]
\therefore \;\; K= log^{-1}(0.9)=(10)^{0.9}=7.94[/latex] [latex]
\therefore \;\; \frac{a}{bK}=\frac{\left ( \frac{1}{4} \right )}{\left ( \frac{1}{24} \right )\times 7.94}=\frac{24}{4 \times 7.94}=0.755[/latex]

question:
Question 89 For the given system, it is desired that the system be stable. The minimum value
of [latex]\alpha[/latex] for this condition is ______.
solution: Given, [latex]G(s)=\frac{(s+\alpha )}{s^3+(1+\alpha )s^2+(\alpha -1)s+(1-\alpha )} [/latex] and  [latex] H(s)=1[/latex] Characteristic equation of given control system is given by [latex]1+G(s)H(s)=0 [/latex] or, [latex] 1+\left [ \frac{s+\alpha }{s^3+(1+\alpha )s^2+(\alpha -1)s+(1-\alpha )} \right ]=0[/latex] or, [latex] s^3+(1+\alpha )s^2+(\alpha -1)s+(1-\alpha )+s+\alpha =0 [/latex] or,  [latex] s^3+(1+\alpha )s^2+\alpha s+1=0[/latex] Routh's array is For the given system to be stable, there should not be any sign change in the first column of Routh's array. Therefore, [latex]1+\alpha \gt 0 \;or, \; \alpha \gt -1\;\; ...(i)[/latex] Also,  [latex] \frac{\alpha ^2 +\alpha -1}{1+\alpha } \gt 0 [/latex] or,  [latex]   \alpha ^2 +\alpha -1 \gt 0 [/latex] or,  [latex] (\alpha +1.618)(\alpha -0.618) \gt 0 [/latex] or,   [latex] \alpha \lt -1.618[/latex] or,  [latex] \alpha \gt 0.618[/latex] As  [latex] \alpha \gt -1[/latex] (using equation (i)) therefore, [latex]\alpha \gt 0.618 \;\;...(ii) [/latex] Combining condition (i) and (ii), [latex] -1 \lt \alpha \lt 0.618 [/latex] Thus, for the system to be stable minimum value of  [latex]\alpha =0.618.[/latex]

question: Question 90 The root locus of a unity feedback system is shown in the figure. The closed loop transfer function of the system is
solution: This is converse root locus having no zero. As, its [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{K}{(s+1)(s+2)} [/latex] Its converse root locus only valid when [latex]K \lt 0[/latex] So, C.L.T.F.[latex]=\frac{G(s)H(s)}{1-G(s)H(s)} =\frac{\frac{K}{(s+1)(s+2)}}{1-\frac{K}{(s+1)(s+2)}} =\frac{K}{(s+1)(s+2)-K}[/latex]

question: Question 91 In the formation of Routh-Hurwitz array for a polynomial, all the elements of a row have zero values. This premature termination of the array indicates the presence of
solution: When all the element s of a row in Routh-Hurwitz array ends abruptly. i.e all elements of that row have a zero values then, the system will be either unstable or maginally stable. Marginally stable means it will have imaginary roots (two equal and opposite complex roots on imaginary axis of s-plane).

options.A: only one root at the origin

question: Question 92 The state variable formulation of a system is given as [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \dot{x_1}\\ \dot{x_2} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} -2 & 0\\ 0&-1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_1\\x_2 \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix} 1\\1 \end{bmatrix}u[/latex] [latex]x_1(0)=0,x_2(0)=0\ and \; y=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_1\\x_2 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The response y(t) to the unit step input is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} [sI-A]&=\begin{bmatrix} s & 0\\ 0 &s \end{bmatrix}-\begin{bmatrix} -2 & 0\\ 0& -1 \end{bmatrix} \\ &=\begin{bmatrix} s+2 & 0\\ 0 &s+1 \end{bmatrix} \\ [sI-A]^{-1}&=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{s+2} & 0\\ 0 &\frac{1}{s+1} \end{bmatrix} \\ [sI-A]^{-1}[B]&=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{s+2} & 0\\ 0 &\frac{1}{s+1} \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \\ &=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{s+2}\\ \frac{1}{s+1} \end{bmatrix} \\ C[sI-A]^{-1}[B]&=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{s+2}\\ \frac{1}{s+1} \end{bmatrix}=\frac{1}{s+2} \\ G(s)&=\frac{1}{s+2} \\ \frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}&=\frac{1}{s+2} \\ Y(s)&=\frac{1}{s(s+2)}=\frac{1}{2}\left [ \frac{1}{s}-\frac{1}{s+2} \right ] \\ y(t)&=\frac{1}{2}(1-e^{-2t})=\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{2}e^{-2t} \end{aligned}[/latex]

solution:
[latex]A= egin{bmatrix} -2 &0 \ 0& -1 \end{bmatrix}, [/latex]  [latex]B= egin{bmatrix} 1\ 1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]AB= egin{bmatrix} -2 &0 \ 0& -1 \end{bmatrix} egin{bmatrix} 1\ 1 \end{bmatrix}= egin{bmatrix} -2\ -1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] For controllability, [latex]|B \; : \;\;AB|
eq 0 [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;  egin{bmatrix} 1 & -2\ 1& -1 \end{bmatrix}=-1-(-2)=1 
eq 0 [/latex] The system is controllable. [latex]C^T= egin{bmatrix} 1\ 0 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]A^TC^T= egin{bmatrix} -2 &0 \ 0& -1 \end{bmatrix} egin{bmatrix} 1\ 0 \end{bmatrix}= egin{bmatrix} -2\ 0 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] For observability, [latex][C^T\;: \; A^TC^T]

question: Question 94 The signal flow graph for a system is given below. The transfer function [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{U(s)}[/latex] for this system is
solution: Using mason's gain formula, [latex]\Delta =1-[-2s^{-1}-2s^{-2}-4-4s^{-1}] [/latex] [latex]\Delta =1+\frac{2}{s}+\frac{2}{s^2}+4+\frac{4}{s} [/latex] [latex]\Delta =\frac{5s^2+6s+2}{s^2} [/latex] [latex]P_1=s^{-2}=\frac{1}{s^2} [/latex] [latex]P_2=s^{-1}=\frac{1}{s} [/latex] [latex]\Delta _1=1 [/latex] [latex]\Delta _2=2 [/latex] [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{U(s)}=\frac{\Sigma P_k\Delta _k}{\Delta }[/latex] [latex]\;\;\;\;=\frac{\frac{1}{s^2} \times 1+\frac{1}{s} \times 1}{\frac{5s^2+6s+2}{s^2}} [/latex] [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{U(s)}=\frac{s+1}{5s^2+6s+2}[/latex]

question:
Question 95 The open-loop transfer function of a dc motor is given as [latex]\frac{\omega (s)}{V_a(s)}=\frac{10}{1+10s}[/latex]. When
connected in feedback as shown below, the approximate value of [latex]K_a[/latex] that will
reduce the time constant of the closed loop system by one hundred times as
compared to that of the open-loop system is
solution: [latex]\frac{\omega (s)}{V_a(s)}=\frac{10}{1+10s}=\frac{10}{1+\tau s} [/latex] [latex]\tau =10 [/latex] Closed loop systems, [latex]\frac{\omega (s)}{R(s)}=\frac{\frac{10K_a}{1+10s}}{1+\frac{10K_a}{1+10s}}[/latex] [latex]=\frac{10K_a}{1+10K_a+10s} [/latex] [latex]=\frac{\frac{10K_a}{1+10K_a}}{1+\frac{10}{1+10K_a}s} [/latex] According to quetion, [latex]\frac{10}{1+10K_a}=\frac{1}{100}\times 10 [/latex] [latex]1+10K_a=100 [/latex] [latex]K_a=9.9[/latex]

question:
Question 96 The Bode plot of a transfer function G(s) is shown in the figure below. The gain (20 log|G(s)| is 32 dB and -8 dB at 1 rad/s and 10 rad/s respectively.
The phase is negative for all [latex]\omega[/latex]. Then G(s) is
solution: Let,  [latex] G(s)=\frac{K}{s^n} [/latex] [latex]G(j\omega )=\frac{K}{(j\omega )^n} [/latex] [latex]\because[/latex]  Gain=32 dB at [latex]\omega =1[/latex] rad/sec [latex] \therefore \; 20log\left | \frac{K}{1^n} \right |=32 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; 20 log K=32 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; K=39.8 [/latex] [latex]Now,[/latex] [latex] \because \;[/latex] Gain=-8 dB at [latex]\omega =10[/latex] rad/sec [latex]\therefore \; 20log\left | \frac{39.8}{10^n} \right |=-8[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \; 10^n=100 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; n=2[/latex]

question: Question 99 The transfer function of a compensator is given as [latex]G_c(s)=\frac{s+a}{s+b}[/latex] [latex]G_c(s)[/latex] is a lead compensator if
solution: [latex]G_c(s)=\frac{s+a}{s+b} [/latex] [latex]G_c(j\omega )=\frac{j\omega +a}{j\omega +b} [/latex] [latex]\angle G_c(j\omega )=tan^{-1}\frac{\omega }{a}-tan^{-1}\frac{\omega }{b} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;= tan^{-1}\left ( \frac{\frac{\omega }{a}-\frac{\omega }{b}}{1+\frac{\omega ^2 }{ab}} \right )[/latex] For [latex]G_c(s)[/latex] to be a lead compensator [latex] \angle G_c(j\omega ) \gt 0 [/latex] [latex]\frac{\omega }{a} \gt \frac{\omega }{b} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow b \gt a[/latex] Option (A) Satisfies the above equation.

question: Question 100 The feedback system shown below oscillates at 2 rad/s when
solution: The characteristic equation, [latex]\;\;1+G(s)H(s)=0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow s^3+as^2+(k+2)s+(k+1)=0[/latex] Routh array of above equation, [latex]as^2+(k+1)=0 [/latex] For  [latex] s=j\omega \; and \; \omega =2 [/latex] [latex]-a\omega ^2+(k+1)=0 [/latex] [latex]k=4a-1 [/latex] and  [latex] a=\frac{k+1}{k+2}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;\;\; a=0.75 \; and \; k=2[/latex]

question:
Question 102 A system with transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{(s^{2}+9)(s+2)}{(s+1)(s+3)(s+4)}[/latex] is excited by [latex]sin(\omega t)[/latex]
. The steady-state output of the system is zero at
solution: Fpr sinusoidal excitation, [latex]s=j\omega[/latex] [latex] \therefore \;\;G(j\omega )=\frac{(-\omega ^2+9)(j\omega +2)}{(j\omega +1)(j\omega +3)(j\omega +4)} [/latex] For zero steady state output [latex]|G(j\omega )|=0[/latex] [latex] \;\;\;=\frac{(-\omega ^2+9)\sqrt{\omega ^2+4}}{(\omega ^2+1)(\sqrt{\omega ^2+9})(\sqrt{\omega ^2+16})} [/latex] For zero steady state output, [latex]\Rightarrow \; \omega ^2=9 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; \omega =3 \; rad/sec[/latex]

question: Question 103 A two loop position control system is shown below The gain K of the Tacho-generator influences mainly the
solution: [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{s(s+1+k)} [/latex] and  [latex] H(s)=1[/latex] Characteristic equation [latex]1+G(s)H(s)=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; 1+\frac{1}{s(s+1+k)}=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; s(s+1+k)+1=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; s^2+(R+1)s+1=0 [/latex] Comapring with, [latex]s^2+2 \xi \omega _ns+\omega _n^2 [/latex] Natural frequency [latex]\omega _n=1[/latex] remains constant and does not depend on k. [latex] 2 \xi \omega _n=k+1 [/latex] [latex]\xi=\frac{k+1}{2} [/latex] Damping ratio depends on k Peak overshoot [latex]=m_p=e^{-\xi \pi/\sqrt{1-\xi^2}} [/latex] Since, [latex]m_p[/latex] depends on [latex]\xi[/latex] which depends on k. Hence, peak overshoot is influenced by gain (k) of techo-generator.

options.C: Phase shift of the closed loop transfer function at very low frequencies [latex](\omega \rightarrow 0)[/latex]
options.D: Phase shift of the closed loop transfer function at very high frequencies [latex](\omega \rightarrow \infty )[/latex]

question:
Question 104 The response h(t) of a linear time invariant system to an impulse [latex]\delta (t)[/latex], under
initially relaxed condition is  [latex]h(t)=e^{-t}+e^{-2t}[/latex]. The response of this system for a unit step input u(t) is
solution: Transafer function of system is impulse response of the system with zero initial conditions. Transfer function=[latex]H(s)=L(e^{-t}+e^{-2t}) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{s+1}+\frac{1}{s+2} [/latex] [latex]H(s)=\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\left ( \frac{1}{s+1}+\frac{1}{s+2} \right ) [/latex] [latex]R(s)=\frac{1}{s} [/latex]   (step input) [latex]C(s)=R(s)\cdot H(s)=\frac{1}{s}\left ( \frac{1}{s+1}+\frac{1}{s+2} \right ) [/latex] [latex]C(s)=\frac{1}{s(s+1)}+\frac{1}{s(s+2)} [/latex] [latex]C(s)=\left ( \frac{1}{s}-\frac{1}{s+1} \right )+\frac{1}{2}\left ( \frac{1}{s}-\frac{1}{s+2} \right ) [/latex] [latex]C(s)=\frac{1.5}{s}-\frac{1}{s+1}-\frac{0.5}{s+2} [/latex] [latex]Response=C(t)=L^{-1}[C(s)] [/latex] [latex]C(t)=L^{-1}\left [ \frac{1.5}{s}-\frac{1}{s+1}-\frac{0.5}{s+2} \right ] [/latex] [latex]C(t)=(1.5-e^{-t}-0.5e^{-2t})u(t)[/latex]

question:
Question 105 The open loop transfer function G(s) of a unity feedback control system is given
as [latex]G(s)=\frac{k(s+\frac{2}{3})}{s^{2}(s+2)}[/latex] From the root locus, at can be inferred that when k tends to positive infinity,
solution: [latex]G(s)=\frac{k\left ( s+\frac{2}{3} \right )}{s^2(s+2)}[/latex] and [latex] H(s)=1 [/latex] Characteristic equation,  [latex]1+G(s)H(s)=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; 1+\frac{k\left ( s+\frac{2}{3} \right )}{s^2(s+2)}=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; s^3+2s^2+k\left ( s+\frac{2}{3} \right )=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; s^3+2s^2+ks+\frac{2k}{3}=0[/latex] Routh array: As [latex]k \gt 0[/latex], there is no sign change in the 1st column of routh array. So the system is stable and all the three roots lie on LHS of s-plane. For [latex]k \gt 0(k\neq 0)[/latex], none of the row of Routh array becomes zero. So root loci does not cross the [latex]j\omega[/latex]-axis. Number of Zero = Z = 1 Number of poles= P =3 Number of branches terminating at infinity = P-Z = 3-1 =2 Angle of asymptotes [latex]=\frac{(2k+1) \times 180^{\circ}}{P-Z} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\frac{(2k+1) \times 180^{\circ}}{2} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=(2k+1) \times 90^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=90^{\circ} \; and \; 270^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] Centroid=\frac{\Sigma poles-\Sigma zero}{P-Z} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{0+0-2-\left ( -\frac{2}{3} \right )}{2}=-\frac{2}{3}[/latex] Since, all the three branches terminates at [latex]R_e(s)=-\frac{2}{3}[/latex]. So, all the three roots have nearly equal real parts.

options.A: Three roots with nearly equal real parts exist on the left half of the s-plane
options.B: One real root is found on the right half of the s-plane

question: Question 106 An open loop system represented by the transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{(s-1)}{(s+2)(s+3)}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]1+\frac{s-1}{(s+2)(s+3)}=0[/latex] [latex]s^2+6s+5=0[/latex] There is no root in RHS of s-plane.

options.A: Stable and of the minimum phase type
options.B: Stable and of the non-minimum phase type
options.C: Unstable and of the minimum phase type
