question:
Question 107 The steady state error of a unity feedback linear system for a unit step input is
0.1. The steady state error of the same system, for a pulse input r(t) having a
magnitude of 10 and a duration of one second, as shown in the figure is
solution: Let the system is represnted as [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}=\frac{G(s)}{1+G(s)H(s)} [/latex] [latex]H(s)=1 (unity \; feedback) [/latex] [latex]Error=E(s)=\frac{X(s)}{1+G(s)} [/latex] Steady state error for [latex]X(s)=1/s, \; e_{ss}=0.1 [/latex] [latex]e_{ss}=\lim_{s \to 0}sE(s) [/latex] [latex]\;\; =\lim_{s \to 0}\frac{sX(s)}{1+G(s)} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; 0.1=\lim_{s \to 0}\frac{s\cdot \frac{1}{s}}{1+G(s)}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \; 0.1=\lim_{s \to 0}\frac{1}{1+G(s)} [/latex] When input, [latex]X(t)=10[u(t)-u(t-1)] [/latex] [latex]X(s)=10\left ( \frac{1}{s}-\frac{e^{-s}}{s} \right )[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{10}{s}(1-e^{-s}) [/latex] [latex]e_{ss}=\lim_{s \to 0}sE(s)[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\lim_{s \to 0}\frac{sX(s)}{1+G(s)} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\lim_{s \to 0}\frac{s \times \frac{10}{s}[1-e^{-s}]}{1+G(s)} [/latex] [latex]e_{ss}=\lim_{s \to 0}\frac{10(1-e^{-s})}{1+G(s)}=0[/latex]

question:
Question 108 The frequency response of a linear system G([latex]j \omega[/latex]) is provided in the tubular form
below Gain Margin and phase margin are
solution: At gain crossover frequency [latex](\omega_{gc})[/latex], magnitude of [latex]G(j\omega)[/latex] is 1. [latex]|G(j\omega_{gc})|=1 [/latex] Phase of [latex]G(j\omega )=\angle G(j\omega_{gc})=-150^{\circ}[/latex] Phase margin[latex]=180^{\circ}+\angle G(j\omega_{gc})[/latex] [latex]\;\;\; =180^{\circ}-150^{\circ}=30^{\circ} [/latex] At phase cross frequency [latex](\omega_{pc})[/latex], phase of [latex]G(j\omega )[/latex] is [latex]-180^{\circ}[/latex], [latex]\angle G(j\omega_{pc})=-180^{\circ}[/latex] M=magnitude of [latex]G(j\omega )[/latex] at [latex]\omega _{pc}[/latex] [latex]=|G(j\omega_{pc})|=0.5[/latex] Gain margin [latex]=20log\frac{1}{M}[/latex] [latex] =20 log \frac{1}{0.5}=6 dB[/latex]

question: Question 109 The characteristic equation of a closed-loop system is s(s+1)(s+3)k(s+2)=0, [latex]k \gt 0[/latex]. Which of the following statements is true ?
solution: Characteristic equation, [latex]s(s+1)(s+3)+k(s+2)=0 [/latex] [latex]1+\frac{k(s+2)}{s(s+1)(s+3)}=0[/latex] Comparing with [latex]1+G(s)H(s)=0 [/latex] [latex]G(s)H(s)=[/latex] open-loop transfer function (OLTF) [latex]=\frac{k(s+2)}{s(s+1)(s+2)}[/latex] Number of zeros=Z=1 zero at -2 Number of poles = P= 3 poles at 0, -1 and -3 Number of branches terminating at infinity [latex]= P-Z = 3-1 =2[/latex] Angle of asymptotes [latex]=\frac{(2k+1)\times 180^{\circ}}{P-Z} [/latex] [latex]=\frac{(2k+1)\times 180^{\circ}}{2} [/latex] [latex]=(2k+1) \times 90^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]=90^{\circ} \; and \; 270^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]Centroid=\frac{\Sigma poles -\Sigma zeros}{P-Z} [/latex] [latex]=\frac{0-1-3-(-2)}{2}=1[/latex] Breakaway point lies in the range [latex]-1 \lt Re[s] \lt 0[/latex] and two branches terminates at infinityalong the asymptotes [latex]Re(s)=-1[/latex].

options.B: It cannot have a breakaway point in the range[latex]-1 \lt Re[s] \lt 0[/latex]
options.C: Two of its roots tend to infinity along the asymptotes Re[s] =-1
options.D: It may have complex roots in the right half plane.

question: Question 110 The system [latex]\dot{x}=Ax+Bu[/latex] with [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} -1 &2 \\ 0&2 \end{bmatrix},B=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} -1 &2 \\ 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] and [latex] B=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex][sI-A]=\begin{bmatrix} s & 0\\ 0 & s \end{bmatrix}-\begin{bmatrix} -1 &2 \\ 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]=\begin{bmatrix} s+1 &-2 \\ 0 & s-2 \end{bmatrix} [sI-A]^{-1}[/latex] [latex]=\frac{\begin{bmatrix} s-1 &2 \\ 0 & s+1 \end{bmatrix}}{(s+1)(s+2)}\;\;...(i)[/latex] Transfer function [latex]= C[sI-A]^{-1}B[/latex] So, denominator of equation (i) gives pole of the system. [latex](s+1)(s-2)=0 [/latex] [latex]s=-1 \; and \; 2 [/latex] One pole lies in RHS of s-plane. Hence, system is unstable. For controllability, [latex]Q_c[/latex] is defined as [latex]Q_c=\begin{bmatrix} B\; : & AB \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]AB=\begin{bmatrix} -1 &2 \\ 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 2 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]Q_C=\begin{bmatrix} 0 &2 \\ 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]|Q_c|\neq 0[/latex] Hence the system is controllable.

question: Question 111 The frequency response of [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{s(s+1)(s+2)}[/latex] plotted in the complex [latex]G(j\omega )[/latex] plane (for [latex]0 \lt \omega \lt \infty[/latex]) is

Question 112 For the system 2/(s+1), the approximate time taken for a step response to reach
98% of the final value is
solution: [latex]\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{2}{s+1} [/latex] [latex]R(s)=\frac{1}{s}(step-input) [/latex] [latex]C(s)=R(s)\left ( \frac{2}{s+1} \right )[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{2}{s(s+1)} =2\left ( \frac{1}{s} -\frac{1}{s-1}\right ) [/latex] [latex]C(t)=L^{-1}[C(s)]=2[-1-e^{-t}] [/latex] Final value of [latex]C(t)=C_{ss}=2[/latex] 98% of [latex]C_{ss}=0.98 \times 2=1.96[/latex] Let,  [latex] t=T[/latex], the response reaches 98% of its final values. [latex]1.96=2[1-e^{-T}][/latex] [latex] T\approx 4 sec[/latex]

question:
Question 113 As shown in the figure, a negative feedback system has an amplifier of gain 100
with [latex]\pm[/latex]10% tolerance in the forward path, and an attenuator of value 9/100 in
the feedback path. The overall system gain is approximately :
solution: [latex]G=100\pm 10[/latex]% [latex] \frac{\Delta G}{G}=10[/latex]% or 0.1 [latex]H=\frac{9}{100}[/latex] Overall gain, [latex]T=\frac{G}{1+GH} [/latex] [latex]T=\frac{100}{1+100 \times \frac{9}{100}}=10[/latex] Sensitivity w.r.t.  [latex]'G'=\frac{1}{1+GH} \times 10[/latex]% [latex] \;\;\;=\frac{1}{1+10 \times 1}\times 10[/latex]% [latex] \;\;\;=\frac{10}{11}\cong 1[/latex]%

question: Question 114 A system is described by the following state and output equations [latex]\frac{dx_1(t)}{dt}=-3x_1(t)+x_2(t)+2u(t)[/latex] [latex]\frac{dx_2(t)}{dt}=-2x_2(t)+u(t)[/latex] [latex]y(t)=x_1(t)[/latex] when u(t) is the input and y(t) is the output The state-transition matrix of the above system is
solution: [latex][sI-A]^{-1}=\frac{\begin{bmatrix} s+2 &1\\ 0& s+3 \end{bmatrix}}{(s+2)(s+3)} [/latex] [latex]=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{s+3} & \frac{1}{(s+2)(s+3)}\\ 0 & \frac{1}{s+2} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex] =\begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{s+3} & \frac{1}{s+2}-\frac{1}{s+3}\\ 0 & \frac{1}{s+2} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] State transition matrix [latex]=L^{-1}[[sI-A]^{-1}] [/latex] [latex]=L^{-1}\begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{s+3} & \frac{1}{s+2}-\frac{1}{s+3}\\ 0 & \frac{1}{s+2} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex]=\begin{bmatrix} e^{-3t} &e^{-2t}-e^{-3t} \\ 0& e^{-2t} \end{bmatrix}[/latex]

question: Question 115 A system is described by the following state and output equations [latex]\frac{dx_1(t)}{dt}=-3x_1(t)+x_2(t)+2u(t)[/latex] [latex]\frac{dx_2(t)}{dt}=-2x_2(t)+u(t)[/latex] [latex]y(t)=x_1(t)[/latex] when u(t) is the input and y(t) is the output The system transfer function is
solution: Selecting [latex]x_1(t)[/latex] and [latex]x_2(t)[/latex] as state variable, [latex]\begin{aligned} \dot{x}_1(t)&=\frac{dx_1(t)}{dt} \\&=-3x_1(t)+x_2(t)+2u(t)  \\ \dot{x}_2(t)&=\frac{dx_2(t)}{dt} =-2x_2(t)+u(t)  \\ \begin{bmatrix} \dot{x}_1(t)\\ \dot{x}_2(t) \end{bmatrix}&=\begin{bmatrix} -3 &1\\ 0& -2 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_1(t)\\ x_2(t) \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}u(t)  \\ \dot{x}&=AX+BU \\ \text{So, } A&=\begin{bmatrix} -3 &1\\ 0& -2 \end{bmatrix}, \; B=\begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}  \\ y(t)&=x_1(t)  \\ y(t)&=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_1(t)\\ x_2(t) \end{bmatrix}  \\ y&=CX+DU \\ \text{So, } C&=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \end{bmatrix} \text{ and } D=0 \\  [sI-A]&=\begin{bmatrix} s & 0\\ 0 & s \end{bmatrix}-\begin{bmatrix} -3 &1\\ 0& -2 \end{bmatrix} \\ &=\begin{bmatrix} s+3 &-1\\ 0& s+2 \end{bmatrix}  \\ [sI-A]^{-1}&=\frac{\begin{bmatrix} s+2 &1\\ 0& s+3 \end{bmatrix}}{(s+2)(s+3)} \\ &\text{Transfer function} \\ &=C[sI-A]^{-1}B+D  \\ &=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \end{bmatrix}\frac{\begin{bmatrix} s+2 &1\\ 0& s+3 \end{bmatrix}}{(s+2)(s+3)}\begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}+0  \\ &=\frac{\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 2(s+2)+1\\ s+3 \end{bmatrix}}{(s+2)(s+3)}  \\ &=\frac{2s+5}{(s+2)(s+3)}=\frac{2s+5}{s^2+5s+6}\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 116 The open loop transfer function of a unity feed back system is given by
 [latex]G(s) =(e^{-0.1s})/s[/latex]. The gain margin of the is system is
solution: Open loop transfer function, [latex]G(s)=\frac{e^{-0.1s}}{s} [/latex] Put,  [latex] s=j\omega [/latex] [latex]G(j\omega)=\frac{e^{-j0.1\omega}}{j\omega}[/latex] At phase crossover frequency [latex](\omega_{pc})[/latex], phase of OLTF is [latex]-180^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]\angle G(j\omega)|_{\omega/\omega_{pc}}=-180^{\circ}=-\pi[/latex] [latex] -\frac{\pi}{2}-0.1\omega_{pc}=-\pi [/latex] [latex]-0.1\omega_{pc}=-\frac{\pi}{2} [/latex] [latex]\omega_{pc}=5 \pi [/latex] [latex]|e^{-0.1\omega}|[/latex] is always 1 for any value of [latex]\omega[/latex] [latex] |G(j\omega)|=\frac{1}{\omega }[/latex] Gain at [latex]\omega_{pc}[/latex] ( phase-cross frequency) [latex] |G(j\omega)|_{\omega_{pc}=5 \pi}=\frac{1}{5 \pi }[/latex] Gain margin [latex]=20 log \frac{1}{|G(j\omega_{pc}|} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=20 log 5\pi=23.9 dB[/latex]

question:
Question 117 The unit-step response of a unity feed back system with open loop transfer
function G(s) = K/((s + 1) (s + 2)) is shown in the figure.
The value of K is
solution: Steady state value of response = 0.75 Input is unit step So steady state error [latex]e_{ss}=1-0.75=0.25 [/latex] [latex]Error=E(s)=\frac{R(s)}{1+G(s)H(s)} [/latex] [latex]where, \;\; G(s)=\frac{k}{(s+1)(s+2)} \;\; H(s)=1 [/latex]  [latex] R(s)=\frac{1}{s} [/latex] Steady state erro using find value theorem, [latex]e_{ss}=\lim_{s \to 0}sE(s) [/latex] [latex]\;\;\lim_{s \to 0}\frac{sR(s)}{1+G(s)H(s)} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\lim_{s \to 0}\frac{s\cdot \frac{1}{s}}{1+\frac{k}{(s+1)(s+2)}}[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{1+k/2} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow\;\; 0.25=\frac{1}{1+k/2} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; k=6[/latex]

question:
Question 118 The asymptotic approximation of the log-magnitude v/s frequency plot of a
system containing only real poles and zeros is shown. Its transfer function is
solution: Initial slope =-40 dB/dec. Hence the system is type-2. So the corresponding term of the transfer function is [latex]1/s^2[/latex]. At [latex]\omega =2[/latex] rad/sec, slope changes by -20 dB/dec from -40 dB/dec to -60 dB/dec. Hence the corresponding term of the transfer function is [latex]\frac{1}{\left ( 1+\frac{s}{2} \right )}[/latex]. At [latex]\omega =3[/latex] rad/sec, slope changes by 20 dB/dec from -60 dB/dec to -40 dB/dec. Hence the corresponding term of the transfer function is [latex]\left ( 1+\frac{s}{5} \right )[/latex]. At [latex]\omega =25[/latex] rad/sec, slope changes by -20 dB/dec from -40 dB/dec to -60 dB/dec. Hence the corresponding term of the transfer function is [latex]\frac{1}{\left ( 1+\frac{s}{25} \right )}[/latex]. [latex]G(s)=\frac{k\left ( 1+\frac{s}{5} \right )}{s^2\left ( 1+\frac{s}{2} \right )\left ( 1+\frac{s}{25} \right )}[/latex] At  [latex] \omega =0.1(\omega \leq 2 \;rad/sec)[/latex] [latex] Gain(dB)=20 \log k-40 \log \omega [/latex] [latex]80=20 \log k-40 \log 0.1 [/latex] [latex]20 \log k=40 [/latex] [latex]k=100 [/latex] [latex]G(s)=\frac{100 \left ( 1+\frac{s}{5} \right )}{s^2\left ( 1+\frac{s}{2} \right )\left ( 1+\frac{s}{25} \right )} =\frac{1000(s+5)}{s^2(s+2)(s+25)}[/latex]

question: Question 119 The first two rows of Routh's tabulation of a third order equation are as follows. [latex]\begin{matrix} s^{3} &2 &2 \\ s^{2}& 4 &4 \end{matrix}[/latex] This means there are
solution: Routh-Array The third row vanishes. An auxillary equation is formed using elements pf 2nd row. Auxiliary equation [latex]A(s)=4s^2+4=0\Rightarrow s=\pm j.[/latex] The derivative of this auxiliary equation is taken w.r.t. s and the cofficient of the differntiated equation are taken as the elements of 3rd row. [latex]\frac{dA(s)}{ds}=8s[/latex] Routh-Array There is no root in RHS of s-plane. Two roots of [latex]s=\pm j[/latex], so one root is in LHS of s-plane.

options.A: Two roots at [latex]s =\pm j[/latex] and one root in right half s-plane
options.B: Two roots at [latex]s =\pm j2[/latex] and one root in left half s-plane
options.C: Two roots at [latex]s =\pm j2[/latex] and one root in right half s-plane
options.D: Two roots at [latex]s = \pm j[/latex] and one root in left half s-plane

question:
Question 120 The polar plot of an open loop stable system is shown below. The closed loop
system is
solution: Two clockwise encirclement of 1+j0. N=-2 Open-loop system is stable [latex]\Rightarrow \; P=0[/latex] N=P-Z -2=0-Z Z= Number of closed loop poles in RHS of 8-plane. Hence the system is unstable.

options.C: unstable with one pole on the RH s-plane
options.D: unstable with two poles on the RH s-plane

question:
Question 121 The state space equation of a system is described by [latex]\dot{x}=Ax+Bu[/latex], [latex]y=Cx[/latex] where [latex]x[/latex] is state vector, u is input, y is output and [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} 0 &1 \\ 0 &-2 \end{bmatrix}[/latex], [latex]B=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}[/latex], [latex]C=[1 \; \; 0][/latex] A unity feedback is provided to the above system G(s) to make it a closed loop
system as shown in figure. For a unit step input r(t), the steady state error in the input will be
solution: [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{s(s+2)} [/latex] and  [latex] H(s)=1[/latex] [latex] r(t)=u(t) [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; R(s)=\frac{1}{s} [/latex] [latex]Error=E(s)=\frac{R(s)}{1+G(s)H(s)} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{\frac{1}{s}}{1+\frac{1}{s(s+2)}} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; E(s)=\frac{s+2}{s(s+2)+1} [/latex] Steady state error, using final value theorem [latex]e_{ss}=\lim{s\rightarrow 0}sE(s) [/latex] [latex]\;\;\lim{s\rightarrow 0}\frac{s(s+2)}{s(s+2)+1}=0[/latex]

question: Question 122 The state space equation of a system is described by [latex]\dot{x}=Ax+Bu[/latex], [latex]y=Cx[/latex] where [latex]x[/latex] is state vector, u is input, y is output and [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} 0 &1 \\ 0 &-2 \end{bmatrix}[/latex], [latex]B=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}[/latex], [latex]C=[1 \; \; 0][/latex] The transfer function G(s) of this system will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \dot{x}&=Ax+Bu \\ \text{and   }y&=Cx \\ \text{where, }  A&=\begin{bmatrix} 0 &1 \\ 0 &-2 \end{bmatrix} \\ B&=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \\ C&=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \\ \text{ and  } D&=0 \\ [sI-A]&=\begin{bmatrix} s & 0\\ 0 & s \end{bmatrix}-\begin{bmatrix} 0 &1 \\ 0 &-2 \end{bmatrix}\\ &=\begin{bmatrix} s &-1 \\ 0 &s+2 \end{bmatrix} \\  [sI-A]^{-1}&=\frac{1}{s(s+2)}\begin{bmatrix} s+2 & 1\\ 0& s \end{bmatrix} \\ & \text{Transfer function} \\ &=C[sI-A]^{-1}B+D  \\ &=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \end{bmatrix}\frac{\begin{bmatrix} s+2 & 1\\ 0& s \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}}{s(s+2)} \\ &=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \end{bmatrix}\frac{\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ s \end{bmatrix}}{s(s+2)} \\ &=\frac{1}{s(s+2)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 123 The transfer function of a system is given as [latex]\frac{100}{s^{2}+20s+100}[/latex]. This system is
solution: [latex]M(s)=\frac{100}{s^2+20s+100} [/latex] Comparing with standard form, [latex]M(s)=\frac{\omega _n^2}{s^2+2 \xi \omega _n s+\omega _n^2} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;2 \xi \omega _n =20 [/latex] [latex]\;\;\omega _n^2=100 [/latex] [latex]\;\; \xi=1 [/latex] [latex]\;\;\omega _n=10 [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]  The system is critically damped.

question: Question 124 Figure shows a feedback system where [latex]K\gt 0[/latex] The range of K for which the system is stable will be given by
solution: [latex]G(s)=\frac{k}{s(s+3)(s+10)} [/latex] and   [latex]  H(s)=1[/latex] Characteristic equation, [latex]\Rightarrow 1+G(s)H(s)=0 [/latex] [latex]\;\; 1+\frac{k}{s(s+3)(s+10)}=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow s(s+3)(s+10)+k=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow s^3+13s^2+30s+k=0 [/latex] Routh-Array According to Routh-Hurwitz criterian. For stable system, signs of first column do not change [latex] k \gt 0 [/latex] and  [latex] \frac{13 \times 30-k}{13} \gt 0 [/latex] Therefore system to be stable [latex]0 \lt k \lt 390.[/latex]

question:
Question 125 The asymptotic Bode magnitude plot of a minimum phase transfer function is
shown in the figure : This transfer function has
solution: Initial slope is -40 dB/decade, it means there are double pole at origin. Slope changes from -40 dB/decade to -20 dB/decade. It means there is a zero. Slope changes from -20 dB/decade to -0 dB/decade at some other frequency.eans ther is one more zero. Therefore transfer function has two poles and two zeros.

question: Question 126 The transfer functions of two compensators are given below : [latex]C_{1}=\frac{10(s+1)}{(s+10)},C_{2}=\frac{s+10}{10(s+1)}[/latex] Which one of the following statements is correct ?
solution: [latex]C_1=\frac{10(s+1)}{(s+10)}[/latex] Zero at s=-1 Pole at s=-10 As zero is closer origin, zero dominates pole. Hence [latex]C_1[/latex] is lead compensator. [latex]C_2=\frac{s+10}{10(s+1)}[/latex] Zero at s=-10 Pole at s=-1 As pole is closer to origin, pole dominates zero. Hence [latex]C_2[/latex] is lag compensator.

options.A: [latex]C_{1}[/latex] is a lead compensator and [latex]C_{2}[/latex] is a lag compensator
options.B: [latex]C_{1}[/latex] is a lag compensator and [latex]C_{2}[/latex] is a lead compensator
options.C: Both [latex]C_{1}\; and \; C_2[/latex] are lead compensator
options.D: Both [latex]C_{1}\; and \; C_2[/latex] are lag compensator

question: Question 127 The transfer function of a linear time invariant system is given as [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{s^{2}+3s+2}[/latex] The steady state value of the output of the system for a unit impulse input applied at time instant t=1 will be
solution: [latex]r(t)= [/latex] unit impulse applied at [latex]t=1 [/latex] [latex]=\delta (t-1) [/latex] [latex]R(s)=1[r(t)]=e^{-s} [/latex] [latex]G(s)=\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{1}{s^2+3s+2} [/latex] [latex]C(s)=R(s)G(s)=\frac{e^{-s}}{s^2+3s+2} [/latex] Steady state value of output, using final value theoram, [latex]C_{ss}=\lim_{s \to 0}sC(s) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\lim_{s \to 0}\frac{se^{-s}}{s^2+3s+2}=0[/latex]

question: Question 128 A function y(t) satisfies the following differential equation : [latex]\frac{dy(t)}{dt}+y(t)=\delta (t)[/latex] where [latex]\delta[/latex](t) is the delta function. Assuming zero initial condition, and denoting the unit step function by u(t), y(t) can be of the form
solution: Taking (L.T.) on both sides [latex]Y(s)(s+1)=1[/latex] [latex] \therefore \;\; Y(s)=\frac{1}{s+1}[/latex] Taking inverse laplace transform [latex]y(t)=e^{-t}u(t)[/latex]

question:
Question 129 Consider the R-L-C circuit shown in figure If the above step response is to be observed on a non-storage CRO, then it would
be best have the [latex]e_i[/latex] as a
solution: [latex]\omega _n=\frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1 \times 10^{-3}\times 10 \times 10^{-6}}} =10^4 [/latex] rad/sec Settling time [latex](t_s)=\frac{4}{\xi \omega _n} =\frac{4}{10^4 \times 0.5}=0.8msec. [/latex] For a square wave T/2 should be grater than [latex]t_s[/latex] For [latex]f_1=50Hz [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \frac{T_1}{2}=\frac{1}{2 \times 50}=10 ms \gt \gt t_s [/latex] For [latex]f_2=300Hz[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \frac{T_2}{2}=\frac{1}{2 \times 300}=1.67 ms \gt t_s [/latex] For [latex]f_3=2kHz [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \frac{T_3}{2}=\frac{1}{2 \times 2 \times 10^3}=0.25 ms \lt t_s [/latex] Therefore, it would be best to have [latex]e_i[/latex] as a square wave of 300Hz.

question: Question 130 Consider the R-L-C circuit shown in figure For a step-input [latex]e_i[/latex], the overshoot in the output [latex]e_o[/latex] will be
solution: [latex]e_i=R_i+L\frac{di}{dt}+\frac{1}{c}\int i \;dt [/latex] Taking Laplace transform, [latex] \begin{aligned}E_i(s)&=\left ( R+Ls+\frac{1}{Cs} \right )I(s)  \\ I(s)&=\frac{E_i(s)}{R+Ls+\frac{1}{Cs} }  \\ e_0&=\frac{1}{C}\int i \;dt \\  \Rightarrow \; E_0(s)&=\frac{1}{Cs}I(s) \\ &=\frac{1}{Cs}\left [ \frac{E_i(s)}{R+Ls+\frac{1}{Cs} } \right ]  \\ t_0(s)&=\frac{E_i(s)}{RCs+LCs^2+1}  \\ \frac{E_0(s)}{E_i(s)}&=\frac{1}{LC\left ( s^2+\frac{R}{L}s+\frac{1}{LC} \right )}  \\  &\text{Characteristic equation,}  \\  \Rightarrow \; & s^2+\frac{R}{L}s+\frac{1}{LC}=0  \\ &\text{Comparing with,}  \\  &s^2+2 \xi \omega _n s+\omega _n^2  \\ \omega _n&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}}  \\ 2 \xi \omega _n&=\frac{R}{L}  \\ \xi&=\frac{R}{L} \times \frac{1}{2\omega _n}  \\  &=\frac{R}{L} \times \frac{\sqrt{LC}}{2}=\frac{R}{2}\sqrt{\frac{C}{L}}  \\  \xi &=\frac{10}{2}\sqrt{\frac{10 \times 10^{-6}}{1 \times 10^{-3}}}=0.5  \\  \text{Overshot }&=P_P =e^{-\pi \xi/\sqrt{1-\xi^2}}  \\  &=e^{-\pi\times 0.5/\sqrt{1-0.5^2}}  \\  & =0.163 or 16.3\%\end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: 0,  since the system is not under damped

question:
Question 131 Consider the feedback system shown below which is subjected to a unit step
input. The system is stable and has following parameters [latex]k_{p}=4,k_{i}=10,\omega =500 \; and \; \xi =0.7[/latex]. The steady state value of z is
solution:
[latex]Step-input \; \Rightarrow R\; (s)=1/s[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}G(s)&=\left ( k_p+\frac{k_i}{s} \right )\left ( \frac{\omega ^2}{s^2 +2\xi \omega s+\omega ^2} \right ) \\ \text{and  }  H(s)&=1\\ \frac{C(s)}{R(s)}&=\frac{G(s)}{1+G(s)H(s)}\\ &=\frac{G(s)}{1+G(s)} \\ E(s)&=R(s)-C(s) \\&=R(s)\left [ 1-\frac{C(s)}{R(s)} \right ] \\&=R(s)\left [ 1-\frac{G(s)}{1+G(s)} \right ]\\ &=\frac{R(s)}{1+G(s)} \\ Z(s)&=\frac{k_i}{s}E(s)=\frac{\frac{k_i}{s}\cdot R(s)}{1+G(s)} \\ \text{Steady} 
 &\text{ state value of Z,} \\Z_{ss}&=\lim_{s \to 0}sZ(s) \\ &=\lim_{s \to 0}\frac{s\cdot \frac{k_i}{s}\cdot \frac{1}{s}}{1+\left ( k_p+\frac{k_i}{s} \right )\left ( \frac{\omega ^2}{s^2 +2\xi \omega s+\omega ^2} \right )} \\ &=\frac{k_i}{k_i\frac{\omega ^2}{\omega ^2}}=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 132 The state equation for the current [latex]I_1[/latex] in the network shown below in terms of the
voltage [latex]V_x[/latex] and the independent source V, is given by
solution: Any state equation represents the dynamical behaviour of the given network. State equations usually follow a specific 'format' while beong represented. On the left side of each state equation, the derivative of only one variable is used. On the right hand side a mathematical function is represnted involving any or all the state varibles and the sources. Using KVL in Loop-I [latex]V-3(I_1+I_2)-V_x-0.5\frac{dI_1}{dt}=0\;\; ...(i) [/latex] Using KVL in Loop-II, [latex]0.5\frac{dI_1}{dt}-5I_2+0.2V_x=0 [/latex] Eliminating [latex]I_2[/latex] from equation (i) and (ii), we get, [latex]\frac{dI_1}{dt}=-1.4V_x-3.75I_1+\frac{5}{4}V[/latex]

question: Question 133 The system shown in figure below can be reduced to the form with
solution: The block diagram can be redrawn as Signal flow graph of the block diagram, There are two forward paths: [latex]P_1=1 \times c_0 \times \frac{1}{s}\times \frac{1}{s}\times P=\frac{c_0P}{s^2} [/latex] [latex]P_2=1 \times c_1 \times 1\times \frac{1}{s}\times P=\frac{c_1P}{s}[/latex] These are four individual loops [latex]L_1=-a_1 \times \frac{1}{s}=-\frac{a_1}{s} [/latex] [latex]L_2=-a_0 \times \frac{1}{s}\times \frac{1}{s}=-\frac{a_0}{s^2} [/latex] [latex]L_3=b_0 \times \frac{1}{s}\times \frac{1}{s} \times P=-\frac{b_0P}{s^2} [/latex] [latex]L_4=b_1 \times \frac{1}{s}\times P=\frac{b_1P}{s}[/latex] All the loop touch forward paths [latex]\Delta _1=\Delta _2=1 [/latex] [latex]\Delta =1-(L_1+L_2+L_3+L_4) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=1+\frac{a_0}{s^2}+\frac{a_1}{s}-\frac{b_0P}{s^2}-\frac{b_1P}{s} [/latex] Using Masson's gain formula [latex]\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{P_1\Delta _1+P_2\Delta _2}{s} [/latex] [latex]\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{\frac{c_0P}{s^2}+\frac{c_1P}{s}}{1+\frac{a_0}{s^2}+\frac{a_1}{s}-\frac{b_0P}{s^2}-\frac{b_1P}{s}} [/latex] [latex]\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{c_0P+c_1Ps}{s^2+(a_0-b_1)s+(a_0-b_0P)} [/latex] [latex]\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{P(c_0+c_1s)/(s^2a_1s+a_0)}{1-(b_0+b_1s)P/(s^2+a_1s+a_0)} \;\;\;...(i)[/latex] [latex]\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{xyP}{1-yzP} \;\;\;...(ii)[/latex] Comparing equation (i) and (ii), we get [latex]xy=\frac{c_0+c_1s}{s^2+a_1s+a_0} [/latex] [latex]yz=\frac{b_0+b_1s}{s^2+a_1s+a_0}[/latex] Hence, Option (D)is correct.

question:
Question 134 If the loop gain K of a negative feed back system having a loop transfer function
[latex]\frac{K(s+3)}{(s+8)^2}[/latex] is to be adjusted to induce a sustained oscillation then
solution: Open loop transfer function, [latex]G(s)H(s)=k\frac{s+3}{(s+8)^2} [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]   Characteristic equation, [latex]\;\;1+G(s)H(s)=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow 1+k\frac{(s+3)}{(s+8)^2}=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow s^2+16s+64+(s+3)=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow s^2+(16+k)s+(64+3k)=0 [/latex] Routh-Array, For sustained oscillation, [latex] \;\; 16+k=0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow k=-16[/latex] Auxillary equation, [latex]\;\;s^2+64+3k=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow s^2+64+3x(-16)=0 [/latex] [latex]\;\;s^2+16=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow s=\pm j4 [/latex] So, frequency of oscillation in 4 rad/sec.

options.A: The frequency of this oscillation must be[latex]\frac{4}{\sqrt{3}}[/latex] rad/s
options.B: The frequency of this oscillation must be 4 rad/s
options.C: The frequency of this oscillation must be 4 or [latex]\frac{4}{\sqrt{3}}[/latex] rad/s
options.D: Such a K does not exist

question:
Question 135 The system [latex]\frac{900}{s(s+1)(s+9)}[/latex] is to be compensated such that its gain-crossover frequency
becomes same as its uncompensated phase crossover frequency and provides a 45[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] phase margin. To achieve this, one may use
solution: Let uncompensated syatem, [latex]T(s)=\frac{900}{s(s+1)(s+9)} [/latex] Phase crossover frequency of uncompensated system [latex]=(\omega _{pc})[/latex], at this frequency phase of [latex]T(j \omega )[/latex] is [latex]-180^{\circ}[/latex] Put   [latex] s=j\omega \text{ in }  T(s) [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} T(j\omega )&=\frac{900}{j\omega (j\omega +1)(j\omega +9)} \\ \angle T(j\omega )&=-90^{\circ}-tan ^{-1}\omega -tan^{-1}\left ( \frac{\omega }{9} \right ) \\ \text{At, } & (\omega _{pc})_1,\angle T(j\omega )=-180^{\circ}\\ -180^{\circ}&=-90^{\circ}-tan^{-1}(\omega _{pc})_1 -tan^{-1}\left ( \frac{(\omega _{pc})_1}{9} \right )\\ -90^{\circ}&=tan^{-1}\frac{(\omega _{pc})_1+\frac{(\omega _{pc})_1}{9}}{1-\frac{(\omega _{pc})^2_1}{9}} \\ \Rightarrow 1-\frac{(\omega _{pc})^2_1}{9}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow (\omega _{pc})_1&= 3 \text{ rad/sec}   \end{aligned}[/latex] Gain cross frequency of compensated system, [latex](\omega _{gc})_2[/latex]= phase cross frequency of uncompensated system, [latex](\omega _{pc})_1[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\;(\omega _{gc})_2=(\omega _{gc})_1=\; 3[/latex]  rad/sec Phase-margin   [latex]=180^{\circ}+\angle T(j\omega )|_{\omega =(\omega _{gc})_2} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; \; \;  45^{\circ}=180^{\circ}+\angle T(j\omega )|_{\omega =(\omega _{pc})_2} [/latex] At     [latex] (\omega _{gc})_2=3[/latex] rad/sec, phase angle of [latex]\angle T(j\omega )[/latex] is [latex] -135^{\circ}[/latex] and phase of uncompensated systen is [latex]-180^{\circ}[/latex] at 3 rad/sec. Therefore, the compensator provides phase lead of [latex]45^{\circ}[/latex] at the frequency of 3 rad/sec. Let X dB is the gain provided by the compensator, so at gain cross frequency, [latex]|T(j\omega )|_{com}[/latex]=1 or 0 dB. Gain of uncompensated system [latex]=|T(j\omega )|_{un-com} =\frac{100}{\omega \sqrt{1+\omega ^2}\sqrt{1+\left ( \frac{\omega }{9} \right )^2}} [/latex] [latex]|T(j\omega )|_{un-com}[/latex] in dB [latex]\;=40-20 \log \omega -20 \log \sqrt{1+\omega ^2} -20 \log \sqrt{1+\left ( \frac{\omega }{9} \right )^2}[/latex] Gain of compensated system, [latex]|T(j\omega )|_{com}=X+|T(j\omega )_{un-com}| [/latex] [latex]|T(j\omega )|_{com}[/latex] must be zero at gain cross frequency [latex](\omega _{gc})_2[/latex] [latex] |T(j\omega_{gc} )_2|_{com}=X+40-20 \log (\omega _{gc})_2 -20 \log \sqrt{1+(\omega _{gc})^2_2}-20 \log \sqrt{1+\frac{(\omega _{gc})^2}{9^2}}=0 [/latex] [latex]X+40-20 \log 3-20 \log \sqrt{1+3^2}-20 \log \sqrt{1+\left ( \frac{3}{9} \right )^2}=0 [/latex] [latex]X=-20dB[/latex] So, the compensator provides an attenuation od 20dB. Hence option (D) is correct.

options.A: a lag compensator that provides an attenuation of 20 dB and a phase lag of 45[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] at the frequency of 3 [latex]\sqrt{3}[/latex] rad/s
options.B: a lead compensator that provides an amplification of 20 dB and a phase lead of 45[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] at the frequency of 3 rad/s
options.C:
a lag-lead compensator that provides an attenuation of 20 dB and phase
lag of 45[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] at the frequency of [latex]\sqrt{3}[/latex] rad/s
options.D:
a lag-lead compensator that provides an attenuation of 20 dB and phase
lead of 45[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] at the frequency of 3 rad/s

question:
Question 136 If [latex]x=Re\; G(j\omega )[/latex], and [latex]y=lm \; G(j\omega )[/latex] then for [latex]\omega \rightarrow 0^+[/latex], the Nyquist plot for
[latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{s(s+1)(s+2)}[/latex] becomes asymptotic to the line
solution: [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{s(s+1)(s+2)}[/latex] Put  [latex] s=j\omega,[/latex] [latex] G(j\omega)=\frac{1}{j\omega(j\omega+1)(j \omega+2)} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\frac{-j(1-j\omega)(2-j\omega)}{\omega (1+\omega ^2)(4+\omega ^2)} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\frac{-j(2-3j\omega -\omega ^2)}{\omega (1+\omega ^2)(4+\omega ^2)} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\frac{-3\omega -j(2-\omega ^2)}{\omega (1+\omega ^2)(4+\omega ^2)} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\frac{-3}{(1+\omega ^2)(4+\omega ^2)}+\frac{ -j(\omega ^2-2)}{\omega (1+\omega ^2)(4+\omega ^2)} [/latex] [latex]=x+iy [/latex] At [latex] \omega =0, \; x\rightarrow -3/4,\; y\rightarrow -\infty[/latex]

question: Question 140 A closed-loop system has the characteristic function [latex](s^{2}- 4) (s + 1) + K(s - 1) = 0[/latex]. Its root locus plot against K is
solution: Characteristic function [latex]\Rightarrow \;\;(s^2-4)(s+1)+k(s-1) [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\;1+\frac{k(s-1)}{(s^2-4)(s+1)}\equiv 1+G(s)H(s) [/latex] Open loop transfer function[latex] =G(s)H(s) [/latex] [latex]=\frac{k(s-1)}{(s^2-4)(s+1)} [/latex] Zero of OLTF s=1; z=1 Poles of OLTS s=-1,-2,+2,P=3 The root locus starts from open-loop poles and terminates either on open-loop zero or infinity. Root locus exist on section of real axis it the sum of the open-loop poles and zeros to the right of the section is odd. Number of branches teminating on infinity. =P-Z=3-1=2 Angle of asymptotes [latex]=\frac{(2k+1)\times 180^{\circ}}{P-Z}[/latex] [latex]=\frac{(2k+1)\times 180^{\circ}}{2} [/latex] [latex]=90^{\circ} \; and \; 270^{\circ}[/latex] Intersection of asymptotes on real axis (centroid) [latex]=\frac{\Sigma poles-\Sigma zeros}{P-Z}[/latex] [latex]=\frac{(-1-2+2)-(1)}{2}=-1 [/latex] Option (B) is correct on the basic of above analysis.

question: Question 141 The Bode magnitude plot of [latex]H(j\omega )=\frac{10^{4}(1+j\omega )}{(10+j\omega )(100+j\omega )^{2}}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]H(j\omega )=\frac{10^4(1+j\omega )}{(10+j\omega)(100+j\omega)^2} [/latex] [latex]H(j\omega )=\frac{(1+j\omega)}{10\times \left ( 1+\frac{j\omega}{10} \right )\times \left ( 1+\frac{j\omega}{100} \right )^2} [/latex] [latex]H(j\omega )=\frac{k(1+j\omega)}{ \left ( 1+\frac{j\omega}{10} \right ) \left ( 1+\frac{j\omega}{100} \right )^2} [/latex] [latex]where \;\; k=\frac{1}{10}=0.1[/latex] Corner frequencys [latex]\omega _1= 1[/latex] rad/sec; [latex]\omega _2= 10[/latex] rad/sec and [latex]\omega _3=100[/latex] rad/sec For frequency less than [latex]\omega _1 \; i.e. \; \omega \lt \omega _1[/latex] Gain of the system is constant aas there is no pole at origin. Gain[latex]=20 log k=20 log 0.1=-20 dB[/latex] At [latex]\omega =\omega _1= 1[/latex] rad/sec or [latex]\omega _1= log 1 =0[/latex] There is zero, so system gain increases with slope +20dB/decades and system gain become 0 dB at [latex]\omega = 10[/latex] rad/sec or [latex]log\omega |_{\omega =10}=log 10=1[/latex] At [latex]\omega _2 =10[/latex] or [latex]log \omega |_{\omega _2=10}=log 10=1[/latex] there is pole, so slope is -20 dB/decade. Overall slope [latex]\omega _2 \lt \omega \lt \omega _3[/latex] = 20 dB/decade - 20 dB/decade = 0 dB/decade So, gain remain constant between [latex]\omega _2 \lt \omega \lt\omega _3[/latex] or [latex]1 \lt log \omega \lt 2[/latex] At [latex]\omega =\omega _3 =100[/latex] rad/sec or [latex]log\omega |_{\omega _3=100}=log 100=2[/latex] the double pole are present. So, system gain decrease with -40 dB/decade.

question: Question 142 For a system with the transfer function [latex]H(S)=\frac{3(s-2)}{4s^{2}-2s+1}[/latex], the matrix A in the state space form X=AX+Bu is equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} H(s)=\frac{Y(s)}{U(s)}&=\frac{3(s-2)}{s^3+4s^2-2s+1} \\ \frac{Y(s)}{X_1(s)}\cdot \frac{X_1(s)}{U(s)}&=3(s-2)\left ( \frac{1}{s^3+4s^2-2s+1} \right ) \\ \text{Let, } \frac{X_1(s)}{U(s)}&=\frac{1}{s^3+4s^2-2s+1}\\  s^3x_1(s)& +4s^2x_1(s)-2sx_1(s)+x_1(s)=u(s)\\ & \text{Replacing s by   } \frac{d}{dt}, \\ \frac{d^3x_1}{dt^2}+4\frac{d^2x_1}{dt^2}&-2\frac{dx_1}{dt}+x_1=u(t)\;\;...(i) \\ \text{Let, }  \frac{dx_1}{dt}&=x_2=\dot{x_1} \\ \frac{d^2x_1}{dt}&=\dot{x_2}=x_3 \\ &\text{Replacing equation (i),} \\ \dot{x_3}&+4x_3-2x_2+x_1=u(t) \\ \dot{x_3}&=-x_1+2x_2-4x_3+u(t) \\ \dot{x_1}&=x_2 \\ \dot{x_2}&=x_3 \\ \dot{x_3}&=-x_1+2x_2-4x_3+u(t) \\ \begin{bmatrix} \dot{x_1}\\ \dot{x_2}\\ \dot{x_3} \end{bmatrix}&=\begin{matrix} 0 &1 &0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\\ -1 &2 &-4 \end{matrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_1\\ x_2\\ x_3 \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}u(t) \\ \text{So, }  A&=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 1\\ -1 & 2 & -4 \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 143 A state variable system [latex]\dot{X}\left ( t \right )=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1\\ 0 & -3 \end{bmatrix}X\left ( t \right )+ \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}u\left ( t \right )[/latex], with the initial condition [latex]X\left ( 0 \right )=\begin{bmatrix} -1, &3 \end{bmatrix}^{T}[/latex] and the unit step input [latex]u\left ( t \right )[/latex] has the state transition equation
solution: ZIR (zero Input Response) [latex]=\phi (t) \times X(0)[/latex] [latex] =\begin{bmatrix} 1 &\frac{}{3}(1-e^{-3t}) \\ 0& e^{-3t} \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} -1\\ 3 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]=\begin{bmatrix} -1+1-e^{-3t} \\ 3 e^{-3t} \end{bmatrix} =\begin{bmatrix} -e^{-3t} \\ 3 e^{-3t} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] ZSR (Zero State Response) [latex]=L^{-1}[(sI-A)^{-1}BU(s)] [/latex] [latex]=L^{-1}\left \{ \begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{s} & \frac{1}{s(s+3)}\\ 0& \frac{1}{s+3} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\frac{1}{s}\right \} [/latex] [latex]=l^{-1}\begin{bmatrix} 1/s^2\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} =\begin{bmatrix} t\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]  State transition equation [latex]\;\;\; =ZIR+ZSR=\begin{bmatrix} -e^{-3t} \\ 3 e^{-3t} \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix} t\\0 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\begin{bmatrix} t-e^{-3t}\\ 3 e^{-3t} \end{bmatrix}[/latex]

question: Question 144 A state variable system [latex]\dot{X}\left ( t \right )=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1\\ 0 & -3 \end{bmatrix}X\left ( t \right )+ \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}u\left ( t \right )[/latex], with the initial condition [latex]X\left ( 0 \right )=\begin{bmatrix} -1, &3 \end{bmatrix}^{T}[/latex] and the unit step input [latex]u\left ( t \right )[/latex] has The state transition matrix
solution: [latex]\dot{x}(t)=\begin{bmatrix} 0 &-1 \\ 0& -3 \end{bmatrix}x(t)+\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}V(t) \;\;...(i) [/latex] [latex]\dot{x}(t)=Ax(t)+Bu(t) \;\;...(ii) [/latex] Comparing equation (i) and (ii), we get [latex]A= \text{System  matrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 0 &1 \\ 0 &-3 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] and [latex]B=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}[sI-A]&=\begin{bmatrix} s &0 \\ 0 & s \end{bmatrix}-\begin{bmatrix} 0 &1 \\ 0 &-3 \end{bmatrix} \\ &=\begin{bmatrix} s &-1 \\ s &s+3 \end{bmatrix} \\ [sI-A]^{-1}&=\frac{\begin{bmatrix} s+3 &1 \\ 0 &s \end{bmatrix}}{s(s+3)-0x(-1)} \\ &=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{s} & \frac{1}{s(s+3)}\\ 0 &\frac{1}{s+3} \end{bmatrix} \\ [sI-A]^{-1}&=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{s} & \frac{1}{3}\left ( \frac{1}{s}-\frac{1}{s+3} \right )\\ 0 &\frac{1}{s+3} \end{bmatrix} \\ &\text{State transition matrix } \\ &=L^{-1}[(sI-A)^{-1}]\\ \phi (t)&=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &\frac{1}{3}(1-e^{-3t}) \\ 0& e^{-3t} \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 145 If the compensated system shown in the figure has a phase margin of [latex]60^{\circ}[/latex] at the crossover frequency of 1 rad/sec, then value of the gain K is
solution: [latex]G(s)=\frac{k+0.366s}{s(s+1)}[/latex]  and [latex]H(s)=1 [/latex] [latex]OLTF=G(s)H(s)=\frac{k+0.366s}{s(s+1)} [/latex] Phase margin=[latex]60^{\circ}[/latex] at  [latex]\omega _{gc}[/latex] (gain crossover frequency) [latex]\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow 180^{\circ}+\angle G(j\omega _{pc} )H(j\omega _{pc})&=60^{\circ} \\ \angle G(j\omega _{pc} )H(j\omega _{pc})&=120^{\circ}\\ -90^{\circ}-tan^{-1}\omega _{gc}+tan^{-1}\left ( \frac{0.366\omega _{gc}}{k} \right )&=120^{\circ} \\ \omega _{gc}&= 1 \text{rad/sec} \\  -90^{\circ}-tan^{-1}(1)+tan^{-1}\left ( \frac{0.366 \times 1}{k} \right )&=120^{\circ} \\ \Rightarrow tan^{-1}\left ( \frac{0.366}{k} \right )&=15^{\circ} \\ \Rightarrow k=\frac{0.366}{tan 15^{\circ}}&=1.366\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 146 In the G(s)H(s)-plane, the Nyquist plot of the loop transfer function
G(s)H(s) = [latex]\frac{\pi e^{-0.25s}}{S}[/latex] passes through the negative real axis at the point
solution: [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{\pi e^{-0.25s}}{s} [/latex] Putting  [latex]s=j \omega[/latex], for frequency response [latex]G(j\omega )H(j\omega )=\frac{\pi e^{-j0.25 \omega }}{j\omega }[/latex] Phase angle [latex]=\angle G(j\omega )H(j\omega ) [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=-90-0.25\omega [/latex] at  [latex]\omega _{pc}[/latex] nyquist plot cuts negative real axis and this frequency [latex]\angle G(j\omega _{pc} )H(j\omega _{pc})[/latex] is [latex]-180^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \angle G(j\omega _{pc} )H(j\omega _{pc})&=-90^{\circ}-\frac{\omega }{4} \\ -180^{\circ}&=-90^{\circ}-\frac{\omega }{4} \\ \omega &=360^{\circ} \text{ or } 2\pi \\ |G(j\omega _{pc} )H(j\omega _{pc})|&=\frac{\pi e^{-j0.25 \times 2\pi }}{j 2 \pi } \\ &=-\frac{j}{2}\left [ cos\frac{\pi}{2}-jsin\frac{\pi}{2} \right ] \\ &=-0.5+j0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 147 When subject to a unit step input, the closed loop control system shown in the
figure will have a steady state error of
solution: Using signal flow graph, Forward path gains [latex]P_{1}=\left ( -1 \right )\times \frac{2}{s+2}=\frac{-2}{s+2}[/latex]  and [latex]P_2=\frac{3}{s}\frac{2}{s+2}=\frac{6}{s(s+2)} [/latex] Individual loop, [latex]L_1=-1 \times \frac{3}{s}\times \frac{2}{s+2}=\frac{-6}{s(s+2)}[/latex] Loop touches forward paths, therefore, [latex]\Delta _1=1 \text{ and } \Delta _2=1 [/latex] [latex]D=1-L_1 =1+\frac{6}{s(s+2)}=\frac{s(s+2)+6}{s(s+2)} [/latex] Using Mason's gain formula, [latex] \frac{Y(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{P_1\Delta _1+P_2\Delta _2}{\Delta } =\frac{-\frac{2}{s+2}\times 1+\frac{6}{s(s+2)}\times 1}{\frac{s(s+2)+6}{s(s+2)}} [/latex] [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{6-2s}{s^2+2s+6} [/latex] For unit step input, [latex]R(s)=\frac{1}{s}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} Y(s)&=R(s)\cdot \left ( \frac{6-2s}{s^2+2s+6} \right ) \\ Error&=E(s)=R(s)-Y(s) \\&=R(s)-R(s)\left (\frac{6-2s}{s^2+2s+6} \right ) \\ &=R(s)\left [ 1-\frac{6-2s}{s^2+2s+6} \right ]\\ E(s)&=\frac{1}{s}\left [ \frac{s^2+4s}{s^2+2s+6} \right ] \end{aligned}[/latex] Steady state value of error, using final value theoram, [latex]\begin{aligned}e_{ss}&=\lim_{s\rightarrow 0}sE(s) \\ &=\lim_{s\rightarrow 0}s\left [ \frac{1}{s}\cdot \frac{s^2+4s}{s^2+2s+6} \right ] \\ &=\lim_{s\rightarrow 0}\left [ \frac{s^2+4s}{s^2+2s+6} \right ]=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 148 A unity feedback system, having an open loop gain [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{K(1-s)}{(1+s)}[/latex], becomes stable when
solution: Characteristic equation [latex]\;\;1+G(s)H(s)=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow 1+\frac{K(1-s)}{1+s}=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow s+1+K(1-s)=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow s(1-K)+1+K=0[/latex] [latex] \;\;s=\frac{K+1}{K-1}[/latex] For a stable system pole lies in left hand side of s-plane, it means, must be negative for stable system. [latex]s \lt 0[/latex] [latex] \frac{K+1}{K-1} \lt 0[/latex] CASE-I: [latex]K+1 \lt 0 \text{ and } K-1 \gt 0 [/latex] [latex]K \lt -1 \text{ and } K \gt 1 [/latex] which is not possible CASE-II: [latex]K+1 \gt 0 \text{ and } K-1 \lt 0[/latex] [latex] K \gt -1 \text{ and } K \lt 1[/latex] [latex] -1 \lt K \lt 1 [/latex] [latex]|K| \lt 1[/latex]

function [latex]G(s)=\frac{(s+1)}{s^{2}}[/latex] is

question:
Question 150 Figure shows the root locus plot (location of poles not given) of a third order
system whose open loop transfer function is
solution: These are three asymptotes with angle [latex]60^{\circ},180^{\circ}[/latex] and [latex]300^{\circ} [/latex] Angle of asymptotes [latex]=\frac{(2k+1)\times 180^{\circ}}{P-Z}[/latex] Where, k=0,1,2 up to (P-Z)-1 as angle are [latex]60^{\circ},180^{\circ}[/latex] and [latex]300^{\circ}[/latex] it means P-Z=3 Intersection of asymptotes on real axis [latex]x=\frac{\Sigma poles -\Sigma zeros}{P-Z}[/latex] Since, system does not have zeroes [latex]x=\frac{\Sigma poles}{P} [/latex] As asymptotes intersect at origin, it means all the three poles are on right Hence, Option (A) is correct.

question: Question 151 A system with zero initial conditions has the closed loop transfer function [latex]T(s)=\frac{s^{2}+4}{(s+1)(s+4)}[/latex]. The system output is zero at the frequency
solution: [latex]T(s)=\frac{s^2+4}{(s+1)(s+4)} [/latex] For frequency response, put [latex]s=j\omega[/latex] [latex] T(j\omega )=\frac{(j\omega )^2+4}{(j\omega +1)(j\omega +4)}=\frac{4-\omega ^2}{(1+j\omega )(4+j\omega )}[/latex] Magnitude of [latex]T(j\omega )=|T(j\omega )|=\frac{4-\omega ^2}{\sqrt{(1+\omega ^2)(16+\omega )^2}}=0[/latex] [latex] \omega =2[/latex]  rad/sec The system output is zero at 2 rad/sec.

question: Question 152 The open loop transfer function of a unity feedback control system is given as [latex]G\left ( s \right )=\frac{as+1}{s^{2}}[/latex] The value of 'a' to give a phase margin of [latex]45^{\circ}[/latex] is equal to
solution: [latex]G(s)=\frac{as+1}{s^2} [/latex] [latex]\omega _g[/latex] = gain crossover frequency at which open gain is loop Phase margin[latex]=180+\angle G(j\omega ) [/latex] [latex]45^{\circ}=180^{\circ}+\angle G(j\omega_g ) [/latex] [latex]\angle G(j\omega_g =-130^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]\angle G(j\omega_g )=\frac{ja \omega _g +1}{(j\omega _g)^2} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=-2 \times 90^{\circ}+tan^{-1}a\omega _g [/latex] [latex]\angle G(j\omega_g )=-180^{\circ}+tan^{-1}a\omega _g=-135^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]tan^{-1}a\omega _g=45^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]a\omega _g=1 [/latex] [latex]\omega _g=\frac{1}{a} [/latex] [latex]Gain=|G(j\omega_g )|=1 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \frac{\sqrt{1+a^2\omega ^2_g}}{\omega ^2_g}=1[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \frac{\sqrt{1+a^2 \times \frac{1}{a^2}}}{1/a^2}=1 [/latex] [latex]\frac{1}{a^2}=\sqrt{2}[/latex] [latex] a=\frac{1}{2^{1/4}}=0.841[/latex]

question:
Question 153 In the system shown in figure, the input x(t)=sint. In the steady-state, the
response y(t) will be
solution: [latex]x(t)=\sin t =1 \lt 0 [/latex] [latex]\omega =1 \;rad/sec[/latex] Transfer function [latex]=G(s)=\frac{s}{s+1}[/latex] For sinusoidal input, [latex]s=j\omega =j [/latex] [latex]G(j\omega )|_{\omega =1}=\frac{j\omega }{j\omega +1}=\frac{j}{j+1}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\angle 45^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]y(t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\angle 45^{\circ}.1 \angle 0^{\circ}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\angle 45^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]y(t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin (t+45^{\circ})[/latex]

question:
Question 154 The unit impulse response of a second order under-damped system starting
from rest is given by [latex]c(t) = 12.5e^{-6t}sin8t,\; t\geq 0[/latex] The steady-state value of the unit step response of the system is equal to
solution: Transfer function of a system is the unit impulse response of the system. Transfer function=[latex]\frac{C\left ( s \right )}{R\left ( s \right )}=\left [ 12.5e^{-6t}\sin 8t \right ][/latex] [latex]\; \; \; \; =12.5\times \frac{8}{\left ( s+6 \right )^{2}+8^{2}}=\frac{100}{\left ( s+6 \right )^{2}+8^{2}}[/latex] when input is unit step, R(s)=[latex]\frac{1}{s}[/latex] [latex]\; \; C\left ( s \right )=\frac{1}{s}.\frac{100}{\left ( s+6 \right )^{2}+8^{2}}[/latex]Steady-state value of response, using final value theorem [latex]C_{steady-state}=\lim_{s\rightarrow \infty }C\left ( t \right )=\lim_{s\rightarrow 0}s\left ( s \right )[/latex] [latex]\; \; \; \; =\lim_{s\rightarrow 0}s\left [ \frac{1}{s}.\frac{100}{\left ( s+6 \right )^{2}+8^{2}} \right ]=1[/latex]

question:
Question 155 The block diagram of a closed loop control system is given by figure. The values
of K and P such that the system has a damping ratio of 0.7 and an undamped
natural frequency [latex]\omega _n[/latex] of 5 rad/sec, are respectively equal to
solution: [latex]G(s)=\frac{k}{s(s+2)} [/latex] and [latex] H(s)=1+sP[/latex] Closed-loop transfer function, [latex]T(s)=\frac{G(s)}{1+G(s)H(s)} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{\frac{k}{s(s+2)}}{1+\frac{k}{s(s+2)}\cdot (1+sP)} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{k}{s(s+2)+k(1+sP)} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; T(s)=\frac{k}{s^2+(2+kP)s+k} [/latex] So, characteristic equation [latex]= s^2+(2+kP)s+k[/latex] Comparing with standard equation  [latex]=s^2+2\xi \omega _n s+\omega _n^2[/latex] [latex]\;\;\; k=\omega _n^2=5^2=25 [/latex] (where [latex]\omega _n = [/latex] undamped natueal frequency) [latex]\;\; 2\xi \omega _n=2+kP[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \; 2 \times 0.7 \times 5=2+25P [/latex] (where [latex]\xi =[/latex] damping ratio) [latex]P=0.2[/latex]

question:
Question 156 The state variable description of a linear autonomous system is X=AX, where
X is the two dimensional state vector and A is the system matrix given by [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 2\\ 2&0 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]. The roots of the characteristic equation are
solution: System matrix [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} 0 &2 \\ 2& 0 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]sI-A=\begin{bmatrix} s & 0\\ 0 & s \end{bmatrix}-\begin{bmatrix} 0 &2 \\ 2& 0 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\begin{bmatrix} s &-2 \\ -2& s \end{bmatrix} [/latex] Characteristic equation [latex]\Rightarrow |sI-A|=0 [/latex] [latex]\begin{bmatrix} s &-2 \\ -2& s \end{bmatrix}=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; s^2-4=0 [/latex] Roots of the characteristic equation are -2 and +2.

question: Question 157 For the block diagram shown in figure, the transfer function [latex]\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}[/latex] is equal to
solution: Method-1: Using block-diagram reduction technique. So, transfer function [latex]\; \; \; \; =\frac{C\left ( s \right )}{R\left ( s \right )}=\frac{s^{2}+s+1}{s^{2}}[/latex] Method-2: Using signal flow graph Three forward paths, [latex]P_{1}=\frac{1}{s}\frac{1}{s}=\frac{1}{s^{2}},\: P_{2}=1.\frac{1}{s}=\frac{1}{s} and P_{3}=1[/latex] The number of individual loap=0 So graph determinant=[latex]\Delta[/latex]=1 and [latex]\Delta _{1}=\Delta _{2}=\Delta _{3}=1[/latex] Applying Mason's gain formula [latex]\; \; G\left ( s \right )\, =\, \frac{C\left ( s \right )}{R\left ( s \right )}[/latex] [latex]\; \; \; \; =\frac{P_{1}\Delta _{1}+P_{2}\Delta _{2}+P_{3}\Delta _{3}}{\Delta }[/latex] [latex]\; \; \; \; =\frac{\frac{1}{s^{2}.1}+\frac{1}{s}.1+1.1}{1}=\frac{s^{2}+s+1}{s^{2}}[/latex]

question: Question 158 For the equation, [latex]s^{3}-4s^{2}+ s + 6 = 0[/latex] the number of roots in the left half of s-plane will be
solution: [latex]s^3-4s^2+s+6=0[/latex] The routh-array is formed as follow: Number of sign changes in forst column of Routh array =2 According to Routh-Hurwitz criterion, the number of changes of sign in the first column gives the number of positive real part roots of the polynomial. So, number of roots in RHS of s-plane=2 Ttoal number of roots=3 Hence, no of roots in LHS of s-plane =3-2=1

question:
Question 159 For a tachometer, if [latex]\theta \left ( t \right )[/latex] is the rotor displacement in radians, e(t) is the output
voltage and [latex]K_{t}[/latex] is the tachometer constant in V/rad/sec, then the transfer
function, [latex]\frac{E(s)}{\Theta(s)}[/latex] will be
solution: [latex]\theta \left ( t \right )=[/latex]rotor displacement in radians [latex]\omega \left ( t \right )=\frac{d\theta }{dt}=[/latex]angular speed in rad/sec Output voltage;  e(t)=[latex]K_{t}\omega \left ( t \right )=\, K_{t}\frac{d\theta }{dt}[/latex] Taking laplace transform on both sides [latex]\; \; \; \; E\left ( s \right )\, =\, K_{t}s\theta \left ( s \right )[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; \; \; \frac{E\left ( s \right )}{\theta \left ( s \right )}\, =\, K_{t}s[/latex]

question:
Question 160 The Nyquist plot of loop transfer function G(s)H(s) of a closed loop control
system passes through the point (-1,j0) in the G(s)H(s) plane. The phase
margin of the system is
solution: [latex]\omega _g[/latex] is gain cross over frequency at which the gain [latex]|G(j\omega) H(j\omega)|[/latex] becomes unity. In this case, phase [latex]\angle G(j\omega) H(j\omega)[/latex] is [latex]-180^{\circ}[/latex] at [latex]\omega =\omega _g[/latex]. [latex]\phi =-180^{\circ} [/latex] So phase margin [latex]=180^{\circ}+\phi =0^{\circ}[/latex]

question:
Question 161 The block diagram of a control system is shown in figure. The transfer function
G(s) = Y(s)/U(s) of the system is
solution: Integrator are represented as 1/s in s-domain As per the block diagram, the corresponding signal flow graph is drawn One forward path [latex]P_{1}\, =\, 2/s^{2}[/latex] The individual loops are, [latex]\; \; \; L_{1}\, =\, -\frac{3}{s},\: L_{2}\, =\, -\frac{12}{s} and L_{3}\, =\, -\frac{18}{s^{2}}[/latex] [latex]L_{1}[/latex] and [latex]L_{2}[/latex] are non-touching loops [latex]\; \; \; L_{1}L_{2}\, =\, \frac{36}{s^{2}}[/latex] The loops touches the forward path [latex]\Delta _{1}=1[/latex] The graph determinant is [latex]\; \; \; \Delta \, =\, 1-\left ( L_{1}+L_{2}+L_{3} \right )+L_{1}L_{2}[/latex] [latex]\; \; \; \; =1+\frac{3}{s}+\frac{12}{s}+\frac{18}{s^{2}}+\frac{36}{s^{2}}[/latex] Applying mason's gain formula, [latex]\; \; \; G\left ( s \right )=\frac{Y\left ( s \right )}{U\left ( s \right )}=\frac{P_{1}\Delta _{1}}{\Delta }[/latex] [latex]\; \; \; \; =\frac{2/s^{2}}{1+\frac{3}{s}+\frac{12}{s}+\frac{18}{s^{2}}+\frac{36}{s^{2}}}[/latex] [latex]\; \; \; \; =\frac{2}{s^{2}+15s+54}=\frac{2}{\left ( s+9 \right )\left ( s+6 \right )}[/latex] [latex]\; \; \; \; =\frac{1}{27\left ( 1+\frac{s}{9} \right )\left ( 1+\frac{s}{6} \right )}[/latex]

question:
Question 162 The asymptotic Bode plot of the transfer function [latex]\frac{K}{1 + \frac{s}{a}}[/latex] is given in
figure. The error in phase angle and dB gain at a frequency of [latex]\omega = 0.5[/latex] are
respectively
solution: Transfer function[latex]=G(s)=\frac{k}{1+\frac{s}{a}} [/latex] Put  [latex] s=j\omega [/latex] [latex]G(j\omega )=\frac{k}{1+j\frac{\omega }{a}} [/latex] Magnitude of [latex]G(j\omega )=|G(j\omega )|=\frac{k}{\sqrt{1+\frac{\omega ^2}{a^2}}}[/latex] Phase of [latex]G(j\omega )\angle G(j\omega )=-tan^{-1\left ( \frac{\omega }{a}\right )} \; at\;  \omega =0.5a[/latex] [latex] |G(j\omega )|_{\omega =0.5a}=\frac{k}{\sqrt{1+\frac{(0.5a)^2}{a^2}}}=\frac{k}{\sqrt{1.25}}[/latex] in dB [latex]=20\log k-20 \log (1.25)^{1/2} [/latex] [latex]=20 \log k-0.97 dB [/latex] From the plot magnitude[latex]=20 \log k[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex]  error in dB gain = 0.97 dB [latex] \angle G(j\omega )|_{\omega =0.5a}[/latex] [latex]=-tan^{-1}\left ( \frac{0.5a}{a} \right )[/latex] [latex]=26.56^{\circ}[/latex] Since it is [latex]-45^{\circ}/dec [/latex] (-ve slope) at [latex]\omega =0.5a[/latex] phase [latex]=-22.5^{\circ}[/latex] Error in phase of [latex]\angle G(j\omega )|_{\omega =0.5a} [/latex] [latex]=-22.5-(-26.56) [/latex] [latex]=+4.06^{\circ}\approx +4.9^{\circ}[/latex]

question: Question 163 The loop gain GH of a closed loop system is given by the following expression [latex]\frac{K}{s(s+2)(s+4)}[/latex] The value of K for which the system just becomes unstable is
solution: Characteristic equation = 1 + GH = 0 [latex]\Rightarrow \; \; \; 1+\frac{K}{s\left ( s+2 \right )\left ( s+4 \right )}\, =\, 0[/latex] Characteristic equation, [latex]\Rightarrow \; \; \; s^{2}\, +\, 6s^{2}\, +\, 8s\, +\, K\, =\, 0[/latex] The Routh-array is formed as follows: According to Routh-Hurwitz criterion, for a stable system there should be no charge of sign in the first column of routh array. So, [latex]\; \; \; \frac{48-K}{6} \gt  0[/latex] and [latex]K\gt 0[/latex] [latex]\; \; \; \; \; 0 \lt K \lt 48[/latex] Hence for K=48, the system just becomes unstable.

question:
Question 164 The following equation defines a separately excited dc motor in the form of a
differential equation [latex]\frac{d^{2}\omega }{dt}+\frac{B}{J}\frac{d\omega }{dt}+\frac{K^{2}}{LJ}\omega =\frac{K}{LJ}V_{a}[/latex] The above equation may be organized in the state-space form as follows [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \frac{d^2\omega}{dt^2}\\ \frac{d\omega}{dt} \end{bmatrix}=P\begin{bmatrix} \\frac{d\omega}{dt}\\ \omega \end{bmatrix}+QV_a[/latex] where the P matrix is given by
solution: Let, [latex]x_1=\frac{d\omega }{dt}[/latex] and [latex]x_2=\omega [/latex] [latex]\;\;\; \dot{x_2}=x_1 [/latex] [latex]\frac{d^2\omega }{dt^2}+\frac{B}{J}\frac{d\omega }{dt}+\frac{k^2}{LJ}\omega =\frac{k}{LJ}V_a [/latex] [latex]\frac{d^2\omega }{dt^2}=-\frac{B}{J}\frac{d\omega }{dt}-\frac{k^2}{LJ}\omega + \frac{k}{LJ}V_a [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; \dot{x_1}=-\frac{B}{J}x_1-\frac{k^2}{LJ}x_2+\frac{k}{LJ}V_a [/latex] [latex]\;\;\dot{x_2}=x_1 [/latex] [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \dot{x_1}\\ \dot{x_2} \end{bmatrix}=P\begin{bmatrix} x_1\\ x_2 \end{bmatrix}+QV_a [/latex] where, [latex]P=\begin{bmatrix} -\frac{B}{J} & -\frac{k^2}{LJ}\\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] and [latex]Q=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{k}{LJ}\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]

question: Question 165 The roots of the closed loop characteristic equation of the system shown in figure are
solution: 1+ GH= 0 (characteristic equation), [latex]\; \; \; 1\, +\, \frac{45}{\left ( s+15 \right )\left ( s+1 \right )}\, =\, 0[/latex] [latex]\; \; \; \; \; s^{2}+16s+60\, =\, 0[/latex] [latex]\therefore \; \; \; \left ( s+10 \right )\left ( s+6 \right )\, =\, 0[/latex] [latex]\therefore [/latex] Roots are [latex]\left ( -6,\, -10 \right ).[/latex]

question:
Question 166 The block diagram shown in figure gives a unity feedback closed loop control
system. The steady state error in the response of the above system to unit step
input is
solution: [latex]G(s)=\left ( \frac{3}{s+15} \right )\times \left ( \frac{15}{s+1} \right ) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{45}{(s+1)(s+15)} [/latex] and  [latex] H(s)=1 [/latex] Open loop transfer function [latex]\;\;=G(s)H(s)=\frac{45}{(s+1)(s+15)} [/latex] The system is type-0. Steady state error to unit-step input [latex]e_{ss}=\frac{1}{1+k_p}[/latex] where, [latex]k_p=[/latex]Position error constant  [latex]=\lim_{s \to 0}G(s)H(s) [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; k_p=\lim_{s \to 0}\frac{45}{(s+1)(s+15)}=3 [/latex] [latex]\;\; e_{ss}=\frac{1}{1+k_p}=\frac{1}{1+3}=0.25[/latex] or [latex]25[/latex]%

question:
Question 167 A control system with certain excitation is governed by the following
mathematical equation [latex]\frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}+\frac{1}{2}\frac{dx}{dt}+\frac{1}{18}x=10+5e^{-4t}+2e^{-5t}[/latex] The natural time constant of the response of the system are
solution: Natural time constant of the response depends only on poles of the system. [latex]T(s)=\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{1}{s^2+s/2+1/18} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{18}{18s^2+9s+1} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{(6s+1)(3s+1)} [/latex] This is in the form [latex]\frac{1}{(1+sT_1)(1+sT_2)} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; T_1,T_2=6sec, 3 sec[/latex]

question: Question 168 A second order system starts with an initial condition of [latex]\begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 3 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] without any external input. The state transition matrix for the system is given by [latex]\begin{bmatrix} e^{-2t} & 0\\ 0& e^{-t} \end{bmatrix}[/latex]. The state of the system at the end of 1 second is given by
solution: State transition matrix, [latex]\phi (t)=\begin{bmatrix} e^{-2t} & 0\\ 0& e^{-t} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] Initial conditions, [latex]x(0)=\begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 3 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] Zero input response is given by [latex] x(t)=\phi (t)x(0) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\begin{bmatrix} e^{-2t} & 0\\ 0& e^{-t} \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 3 \end{bmatrix} \;\;=\begin{bmatrix} 2e^{-2t}\\ 3e^{-t} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] State of the system at t=1s [latex]X(t)|_{t=1}=\begin{bmatrix} 2e^{-2}\\ 3e^{-1} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 0.271\\ 1.100 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]

question:
Question 169 A lead compensator used for a closed loop controller has the following transfer
function [latex]\frac{K(1+\frac{s}{a})}{1+\frac{s}{b}}[/latex] For such a lead compensator
solution: Transfer function[latex]=\frac{k\left ( 1+\frac{s}{a} \right )}{\left ( 1+\frac{s}{b} \right )}[/latex] Zero of TF=-a Pole of TF=-b For a lead-compensator, the zero is nearer to origin as compared to pole, hence the effect of zero is dominant, therefore, the lead-compensator when introduced in series with forward path of the trnasfer function the phase shift is increased. So, from pole-zero configuration of the compensator [latex]a \lt b[/latex].

question: Question 170 A control system is defined by the following mathematical relationship [latex]\frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}+6\frac{dx}{dt}+5x=12(1-e^{-2t})[/latex] The response of the system as [latex]t\rightarrow \infty[/latex] is
solution: Taking (LT) on both sides [latex](s^2+6s+5)X(s)=12\left ( \frac{1}{s}-\frac{1}{s+2} \right ) =\frac{24}{s(s+2)} [/latex] [latex]X(s)=\frac{24}{s(s+2)(s+1)(s+5)} [/latex] Responce at [latex]t\rightarrow \infty[/latex] Using final value theorem [latex] \lim_{t\rightarrow \infty }x(t)=\lim_{s \rightarrow 0}sX(s) [/latex] [latex]=\lim_{s \rightarrow 0}\frac{s \times 24}{s(s+2)(s+1)(s+5)}=2.4[/latex]

question: Question 171 For the system [latex]\dot{x}=\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 0\\ 0&4 \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} u; y=\begin{bmatrix} 4 & 0 \end{bmatrix}X[/latex], with u as unit impulse and with zero initial state, the output, y, becomes
solution: [latex]x(t)=e^{At}X(0)+\int_{0}^{t}e^{A(t-\tau) }BU(\tau )d\tau [/latex] [latex]\because \;\; X(0)=0[/latex]  (as given) [latex]\therefore \;\; x(t)=0+\int_{0}^{t}\begin{bmatrix} e^{2(t-\tau )} &0 \\ 0 & e^{4(t-\tau )} \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\delta (t)dt [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\int_{0}^{t}\begin{bmatrix} e^{2(t-\tau )}\\ e^{2(t-\tau )} \end{bmatrix}\delta (t)dt [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\begin{bmatrix} e^{2t}\\ e^{4t} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] Output  [latex]y(t)=\begin{bmatrix} 4 &0 \end{bmatrix}x(t) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\begin{bmatrix} 4 &0 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} e^{2t}\\ e^{4t} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] Hence, [latex]y(t)=4e^{2t}[/latex]

question:
Question 172 The transfer function of the system described by [latex]\frac{d^{2}y}{dt^{2}}+\frac{dy}{dt}=\frac{du}{dt}+2u[/latex] with u as
input and y as output is
solution: [latex]\frac{d^2y}{dt^2}+\frac{dy}{dt}=\frac{du}{dt}+2u [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow s^2Y(s)+sY(s)=sU(s)+2U(s)[/latex] [latex] \therefore \;\; \frac{Y(s)}{U(s)}=\frac{s+2}{(s^2+s)}[/latex]

question: Question 173 A unity feedback system has an open loop transfer function, [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{s^{2}}[/latex]. The root locus plot is
solution: [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{K}{s^2}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \;\;P_Z=2 [/latex] [latex]Centroid=\frac{0}{2}=0 [/latex] Angle of asymptotes[latex]=90^{\circ},270^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \;\;[/latex] Option (B) is correct.

question: Question 174 For the system [latex]\dot{x}=\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3\\ 0&5 \end{bmatrix} X +\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}u[/latex], which of the following statements is true?
solution: [latex]|Q_C|=\begin{bmatrix} 1& 2\\ 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex]  Uncontrollable. Characteristic equation: [latex]|sI-A|=0 [/latex] [latex]\begin{bmatrix} s-2& -3\\ 0 & s-5 \end{bmatrix}=0 [/latex] [latex]s^2-7s+13=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] eigen values, [latex]s =3.5 \pm j0.866[/latex] i.e. roots lies on right side of s-plane . [latex]\Rightarrow [/latex]  unstable.

options.A: The system is controllable but unstable
options.B: The system is uncontrollable but unstable
options.C: The system is controllable but stable
options.D: The system is uncontrollable but stable

Question 176 The asymptotic approximation of the log-magnitude versus frequency plot of a
minimum phase system with real poles and one zero is shown in figure. Its
transfer functions is
solution: Type: 2 Poles : 0, 0, 2, 25 Zeroes : 5 [latex]Gain=m \log \omega +20 \log K [/latex] [latex]54=-40 \log (0.1)+20 \log K [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; K=5 [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; T.F.=\frac{5(1+0.2s)}{s^2(1+0.5s)(1+0.04s)} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\frac{50(s+5)}{s^2(s+2)(s+25)}[/latex]

question: Question 178 Given the homogeneous state-space equaion [latex]\dot{x}=\begin{bmatrix} -3 &1 \\ 0&-2 \end{bmatrix}x[/latex] the steady state value [latex]x_{ss}=\lim_{t\rightarrow \infty }x(t)[/latex], given the initial state value of [latex]x\left ( t \right )=\left [ 10-10 \right ]^{T}[/latex], is
solution: [latex][sI-A]^{-1}=\begin{bmatrix} s+3 &-1 \\ 0 & s+2 \end{bmatrix}^{-1} =\begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{s+3} &\frac{1}{(s+2)(s+3)} \\ 0& \frac{1}{s+2} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]e^{At}=L^{-1}[sI-A]^{-1}=\begin{bmatrix} e^{-3t} & e^{-2t}-e^{-3t}\\ 0 & e^{-2t} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]x(t)=e^{At}X(0) =\begin{bmatrix} e^{-3t} & e^{-2t}-e^{-3t}\\ 0 & e^{-2t} \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 10\\ -10 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; x(t)=\begin{bmatrix} 20e^{-3t}-10e^{-2t}\\ -10e^{-2t} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; X_{ss}=\lim_{t \rightarrow \infty }\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]

solution: Nyquist plot will be [latex]\therefore[/latex] Number of encirclement of (-1,j0)=-2 and number of right sided poles in open loop system=0 [latex]\;\;\;N=P-Z[/latex] [latex] \therefore \;\; -2=0-2[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;\;Z=2 [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]  Closed loop system is unstable with two poles on the right half of s-plane.
